Subject: [sfraves] WR: My Yummy Friday Night Adventure

Part 1

So like ok.. i don't like totally wanna get all emo & shit, but I think I
need to like back story to explain a few things before I give a proper
WR... ooh yeah... to the newbs & resubs to SFRaves, (WR = Weekend Review)
'cause like well.. things got kinda on the accronym tip a while back & I
just thought I'd add to it & it like kinda stuck..

Anywaze, so like yeah, Thursday was the funeral for my Uncle Bobbing who
passed away exactly a week before, the same day another Uncle passed away
in the Phillipines.  A week and a 1/2 before that, my other Uncle in the
hospital passed from ummm... dialisys (sp) complucations... then a week
before that, my Auntie who used to baby sit me after my car accident when
I was 4, died on a plane trip coming back from the Phillipines... I mean..
this whole time like I've been just hardcore mourning Dave, but like I
dunno, everything just got really heavy on the sad tip... so by the time
my Uncle Bobbing passed, it just kinda made like my heart really all the
more heavy & I dunno... it kinda made me like mentally regress back to
missing Dave more while like just being sad that my relatives passed... I
mean, my Uncles & Aunties were up there in age & lived good long
fulfilling lives & well, yeah, i dunno what I'm tryin' to say, it all just
kinda added up & got me in a mondo hardcore funk...  ooh yeah.. Mondo
Thanks to everyone who been helping me get through this :)

Part 2
I kinda wasn't feelin' like going out Friday night, but I already kinda
promised people i'd be Pulse, so i went.. I mean.. I also figure of all
the weeks of yucky that built up in my head, i just needed dance floor &
to be surrounded by my 2nd Family!  Like it was my 1st time back in
Paradise in yeeeeears... that venue got really cute! So yeah... all the
sets were Dope!!!  The residents totally like brought in the vibe w/ their
smooth like tech house kinda breaky electro funky yummy stuff, Alixr &
Dhamma, then like the big outta town DJ, ummm, I think her name is Dory,
she played alota minimal techno, tech house, & alota tribal techno, oh my
goodness, when Birthday Chica Forest got on the decks, man, she rocked the
floor so hard with her Electro House & her hard yummy ear candy stompy
dancefloor goodness... Mozzie played his Glitchy breaks & housey kinda
stuff, & Eric Sharp played his booty bass music... actually, 2 songs I
liked alot from his set were Hatorade & Short Dick Man.. I mean.. they wre
remixes, but it was fun to hear!

So the energy was reeeeally good, there was just a thickness of this yummy
vibe at the club & soooooooooo many people came outta the woodwork from
the old skool days!  There were like so many heads from the old skool that
I got to catch up with!!  My homie Crave from washington State was at the
club too & we hella got to chill!  I did dance alot, but I mean.. well..
so I sprained my ankle like a lil over a month ago @ the Junlge club & it
hasn't fully healed yet, so i couldn't dance too hard really, but man, I'm
kinda pissed @ myself for just not letting go... most of my night I was
just kinda out of it... it probably woulda been better if i just let go &
danced as hard as I could of, but something just held me back, it was
totally lame for me to be like that, but I dunno man.. but still all in
all, the night fuckin' rocked so damn hard & I did get from it what I
could get which was good enough to plaster some yummy memories in my head!
 I mean.. Hello 2day, even like chillin' in the balcony watchin' people
dance & vibin' to the music was good too!!!

All you SFR heads who I got to hang out with & stuff, like seriously..
Thank U for the hugz & all the comfort I needed lastnight!!!

Part 3
So I chilled w/ the crew & helped out a lil after the cluib closed 'cause
I needed time to kill b4 BART opened up.. after all that & alota goodbye
hugz n cuddlze, i had a few seconds to formulate a plan to kill time...
then I realized that I mean, well.. I had my ipod w/ yummy choonage
playing & alota long empty sidewalks, so I figured I could practice my
model walk down the runway to some Janet Jackson & figure out what to do..
walked by 1015 to see if there were anyone I knew was leaving the club or
outside smoking, no one, so I just practiced my model walk down folsum
street somemore!  I ended up at this gay porn store, probably bugging the
fuck outa the cashier with all my questions.. but he musta been freaked
out by some guy comin' in @ 4:30AM with a top hat on & a shiny ass blue
puffy vinyl jacket... yeah.. i also like did price checks on jock straps
'cause I dunno.. it looked like fun to wear from teh pictures on the box..
but didn't buy one 'cause I wan't sure about what size I'd be...

After the gay porn store, I went to 8 flavors Cafe thingie on 5th & almost
Market... while I was eating my crumb donut & drinking my choco milk, i
remembered that my Russian Bronx New Yorker Homie who does the sidewalk
water hose cleaning at Powell bart station was gonna be there... but
unfortunately, by the time I rushed & got there, he wasn't there no more,
but like it was still wet all around there, so he probs just left :(  So I
just waited w/ the few people there for BART to open... I kinda just
walked around kinda singing, hopefully I wasn't too loud...

OK, now this is the trippy part & what kinda lifted my spirits.. as soon
as the BART gates opened up, I started walkin' to the ticket machine.. I
felt this tap on my shoulder, turned around, & saw this lady talkin' to me
& I soooooooooo could not hear her 'cause my ipod was like drowning out
her voice... but yeah.. that lady ended up being my classmate Danielle
from acting school like back in the 90s & we ain't seen each other in
heeeeeeeella years.. so we spent like almost 20 minutes catching up...
like we hella gossiped about like old classmates & what we been up to the
past hella years... Hello 2day, i shouldn't of told her that he
ex-boyfriend used to hit on my when they were dating, but it just kinda
slipped out... but yeah, ooops! That was Dope to see her & well.. she
works for MUNI now too!!

So yeah... that was my Friday night adventure!  i still feel kinda shitty,
& I know it'll be a while for  my head to fully recover from the recent
yucky.. but I'll get there! :)  Thanks again to everyone I saw there from
the list!  I Love y'all lots!!!


 --
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

=54=68=61=6E=6B=73 =66=6F=72 =79=6F=75=72 =73=75=70=70=6F=72=74!!!

----- Original Message ----
From: Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Monday, March 2, 2009 10:45:00 AM
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: tony hewitt / martin o'brien / ravi pina

Please tune in to KZSU by listening to 90.1 in the Bay Area or
pointing your web browser to http://kzsulive.stanford.edu.

If you're interested in guest appearing on any of our shows
or having a mix featured contact us using our email addresses
or: electronicadjs@kzsu.stanford.edu

Big Love Show with Jack - Mon 3PM-6PM Pacific/US
------------------------------------------------

This week Jack is hosting Martin O'Brien and Tony Hewitt.

Martin O'Brien is one of the most prominent figures of Bay Area
underground history. He's the organizer of the legendary "Gathering"
& "Basics" parties in which DJs like Tony, Jeno, Garth, Spun, and
Josh were the residents, and the prevailing sounds of the day were
acid & tribal house. Every old-schooler knows these parties and
every old-schooler knows how influential they were.

You can find out more about Martin O'Brien at:
http://hsomusic.com/sh/43

Tony Hewitt has been working with Mark "Blakkat" Bell to do live
music for the MoMusic events in the Bay Area.

A native of Manchester, England, Tony came to the U.S. in 1988.
While living in Southern California, he discovered L.A.s Underground
warehouse parties where hed hear DJs like Doc Martin, Steve Loria,
Barry Weaver and Michael Cook - who inspired him to start DJing.

In 1992, he moved to San Francisco where he began a residency at the
legendary Gathering parties, Funky Tekno Tribe and guest spots at
Come-Unity. To date, he has dj'd all over the U.S, Canada, Europe and
Indonesia, with guest spots at Fabric in London, the Bomb in
Nottingham, La Terraza in Spain and OTV Club in Croatia.

In the late 90s Tony, Onionz, Hipp-e & Halo, Joeski &  Master D
joined forces as the 6400 CREW and  went on to record for the best
house labels around, like 2020 Vision, NRK, Soma, Yoshitoshi,
Tango, Nightshfit, and Detour.

Also, DO NOT EVER ask him about Machester United - because TRUE
Mancs support Manchester City!

You can find out more about Tony Hewitt at:
http://hsomusic.com/sh/1U

You can find out more about Jack and his show at:
http://www.thebigloveshow.com/

Eclektronik Groove w/ Holt Sorenson - Mon 9AM-12PM Pacific/US
--------------------------------------------------------------

Holt started off the day with an hour mix and now is hosting Ravi
Pina.

Ravi Pina has been involved with dance music in one form or another
for the last 10 plus years.  Starting in Cleveland with promoting
parties and then moving around the country to Boston, NYC, and
finally SF where he now calls home.  His tastes range from trip-hop
and downtempo to deep, funky, soulful, and disco house, but will
play anything as long as it gets you movin'.  After an extended
hiatus, he is slowly working his way back into the scene.

More about Ravi:
http://hsomusic.com/sh/41
http://hsomusic.com/sh/42

Upcoming Events for Holt:
03/08 - The Rhythm Room @ The EndUp
03/15 - The Greenhouse @ Deepmixfm (http://hsomusic.com/sh/1v)

Epiphany of Sound with J.C. - Th 9AM-12PM Pacific/US
----------------------------------------------------

After 14 years, DJ J.C.'s techno/house/electronica showcase has
garnered much attention and devotion. Like most folks at Stanford's
radio station, he's a volunteer, proving that his motivation isn't
a paycheck; it's his passion to share his interest in one of music's
most eclectic genres. With his conversational style, inclusion of
producers and musicians from both the local & international scene,
and his stewardship of the station's 24-hour marathons during
Solstices and Equinoxes, it's no wonder that DJ J.C has made a
connection with listeners in a very crowded market. Catch his live
broadcasts or listen to the previous week's program at underheard.org.

J.C. will email this week if he has an update on any guests.

Thanks for your support!!!

--
Holt Sorenson/Eclektronik Groove
hso@hsomusic.com
hsomusic.com - myspace.com/hsomusic
KZSU (kzsulive.stanford.edu) show Th @ 6-9AM US/Pacific

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: [KONTROL] Sat.Mar.7th w/ Martin Landsky (PokerFlat) + Audio 
	Werner LIVE (Perlon)

Saturday, March 7th, 2009

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every 1st Saturday at The Endup



featuring from Berlin:


MARTIN LANDSKY

(Poker Flat . Dessous . Intim)

Martin Landsky is without a doubt one of the most revered
and sought-after names in underground dance music today.
In addition to running the Poker Flat Nights with Steve Bug
and producing for several ace labels including his own Intim,
his skills behind the decks (including exalted performances
at last year's WMC and DEMF) have raised his profile to
near legendary proportions.  Prepare for a night of sexy and
artful house and techno, paired with the impeccable
programming and flawless mixing Martin has come to be
known for the world over.



and from Cologne:


AUDIO WERNER - LIVE

(Perlon . Hartchef Discos. Hello?Repeat . Ware)
(Circus Company. Trapez . Musique Risqu=E9e)

Audio Werner first caught our ears and won our hearts at
2006's DEMF, where his jaw-dropping live PA stole the
show at the Get Perlonized afterparty. His highly creative,
technically masterful, and relentlessly funky productions
have established a benchmark of quality strived for by
musicians around the globe.  We've wanted to bring him
over for years, and are truly honored to now present a rare
live performance of brand new material by one of our
favorite artists in his SF debut.

___________________________________________________


MARTIN LANDSKY

Unlike any other German protagonist of the electronic dance scene,
Martin Landsky withdrew himself from the well known category of
electronic dance music. The verbal approach is of course only a
portion of the complete and original sound of Landsky=91s music which
combines Techno, House, Minimal and Funk. He has been creating waves
as a sensational DJ and producer since the mid-90's and Landsky has
also been heard and recognized since 2000 as one of the key figures in
the circle of producers at Poker Flat Recordings. The label owner
Steve Bug is also a long term friend of Landsky.

"As a DJ and as musician I try to balance between both traditional
House and Techno music. Despite the fact that I use a lot of reduction
for that electronic sound, it is my duty to create deep music which
must also always include twisty and funky elements=93 says Martin. With
confidant mixing from retrostyle roots to up-to-date Club music, this
all but consequently represents Landsky like hardly any other musician
and DJ of the Poker Flat Style.

The special affinity to the roots of black club music fell in
Landsky=91s sight early on in his life. Through his hobby of
breakdancing as an eleven year old boy, Martin Landsky aquired an
impulsive contact to dance music, from funk to hiphop.  Starting
initially on a tapedeck and then later on his fathers Bontempi organ,
as well as a pitch control record player, it was clear to see from the
first single megamixes he produced that he had lost his heart
hopelessly to the music.

In the beginning DJing was always the most important thing for
Landsky=91s musical identity. He was just fourteen when he first started
to perform at school celebrations  and private parties. Of course the
ultimate moment of his musical carrier came around when he first
visited Hamburg=91s Kultclub Front in 1988. The mixture of Funk and the
growing trend of House, Acid and Techno electrified Landsky like
nothing else before and has affected his musical aesthetics up untill
the present day..  In 1994 his hard work and persistance payed off and
his dream came true when he was offered a regular residency at his
favourite club.

It soon became clear that Landsky would not last the duration as just
an exclusive and shining local heroic DJ and so then started to work
for the newly established distribution department of Container
Records. He then later worked for the distribution company Word and
Sound, and it was through both of these jobs that he gained valuable
contacts which helped him to travel much further afield as a DJ. At
the end of 1999 he made a last and final decision to leave Hamburg and
try his luck in Berlin as a full time DJ and Musician. With the help
of regular Bookings and his friends Cl=E9 and Steve Bug, he helped to
arrange a series of "Poker Flat Nights" at famous "Sternradio" and
regular headliner bookings in some of the most renowned clubs in
Berlin such as E-Werk, the Pfefferbank, Tresor and Casino. He also put
together many Mix CD=91s for labels such as Poker Flat, Systematic and
the Partysan complilation series which turned Landsky into one of the
most important figures in the German Club sound of the year 2000.

Parallel to this and as a result of his music productions, Landsky
gained the status as one of the most important protagonists with a
slightly different understanding of house music. Two years after
Martin Landsky=91s first release in 1995 called "Sampled House Vol. 1"
for Container Records, he then announced the release of his first 12"
the "Horner Corner EP" in 1997 under the name of Pseudonym 'City Nord'
on the London label MC Projects. From this point on Landsky=91s
definition of House music became internationally known.

The following year Martin released his 12=93 "My Hidden Basement" which
was the starting point of his first new label=82 Effortil Records, then
came "Love-Fourty" which was the second release to appear in 1999. His
label, now under the name of Intim Recordings and of course his first
releases for Dessous ("Wild EP") and Poker Flat ("Crude Clay"), made
him acquainted for the first time within a big circle of renown DJ=91s
and producers. Still, in the year 2000 he began working on his first
longplayer for Poker Flat Records, which in the following year brought
his status up to an international level.

"In Between"  was the title of Landskys debut album which was directly
linked to his third Intim-EP "Follow Me" and the Poker Flat Records
12" release "Sweet Sweet Morning". The year 2001 was the most
productive and successful year in Landsky=91s career.

In the Summer of 2003 Landsky had reached a new point in his
understanding of House music. On "Reject" he worked together
intensively with Filip G., an amazing vocalist from Hamburg. Not least
because of the catchy vocals, the single became a massive global club
hit which lasted for weeks in the German club charts and which also
landed Landsky into the playlists of some of the hippest DJs around.
There was also Landsky=91s remix of the single "The Difference" by DK7
which was played to extent up and down the clubs worldwide.

Besides the remixes (for D.H.S., Marc Romboy, Booka Shade, Eyerer &
Chopstick or Namito) In the past, Landsky recently created  some
special moments for club nights with the hits "Fools (They Don't Know
The Time)" from 2004, "FM Safari" (2005) and last but not least "1000
Miles" (2006), a dusky hypnotic masterpiece which is without a doubt
Landsky=91s most successful piece of work. More recently "Let me Dance"
was the next track to follow up in the footsteps of "1000 Miles".


*** Resident Advisor on Landsky's return to NYC:

"Does Martin Landsky play the sexiest techno in the business? After
blow-up sets in Miami and Detroit last year coupled with a devastating
afterhours performance at Rebel for Sunday School for Degenerates New
York, Martin returns for a follow-up lesson in house, techno, with
hints of acid. The Intim label headmaster puts together a portfolio
with everything from flawless mixing to sexy vocals that shows why he
is hailed as one of the top DJs in the upper class of the Techno
community."


=3D=3D=3D> LINKS:

Martin Landsky's website:
http://www.landsky.de/

Martin Landsky's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/martin%20landsky

Martin Landsky on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/mlandsky


=3D=3D=3D> AUDIO:

Martin Landsky - Live @ Oslo, Detroit  05.25.08
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K45/Martin_Landsky_@_Oslo_-_DEMF08.mp3


=3D=3D=3D> VIDEO:

Martin Landsky @ Kecel Fest, 2007
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Dh5iRB7dC5-k

Martin Landsky @ Romy S, Stuttgart - 2008
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DVti0LcXUxgU


__________________________________________________________________


AUDIO WERNER

Andreas Werner is one of today's most prolific figures in the
incredible techno universe of Cologne. He encapsulates a delicate
rhythmic sound and expression that is best exemplified in his 12=94
'Zwrtshak Drive'=97a favorite among artists such as Guido Schneider,
Richie Hawtin and Ricardo Villalobos. It was also a #1 selection in
the German publication Groove Magazine.

Supported in recent years by Triple R (head of the Traum label) under
his pseudonym Audio Werner, Andreas has developed a sound that has
renewed and continued the refined techno tradition in Cologne=97the
flagship European city for electronic music over the last decade.

Audio Werner has had releases on Perlon, Hello?Repeat, Traum, Trapez,
Moon Harbour, Ware, and his own Hartchef Discos, disseminating his
meticulous works that today still reveal many fresh nuances. His sound
is part of a genre that the Germans gravitate to consistently and not
without palpable success, especially considering the adversity towards
decadent raves in recent memory.

Both contemplative and functional, his musical style is a voice for
artistic minimalism in Cologne and serves as a reference for the
entire international scene.


=3D=3D=3D> LINKS:

Audio Werner's website:
http://www.hartchef.de

Audio Werner's discography
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Audio%20Werner

Audio Werner on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/audiowerner


=3D=3D=3D> AUDIO:

Audio Werner - DJ set @ Crossroads, Tokyo  06.23.07
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K45/Audio_Werner_-_DJ_set_2007.mp3


=3D=3D=3D> VIDEO:

Audio Werner @ Subway, Koln - 2008
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DvKFOnDH--dU

Audio Werner @ LesIzMor, Brussels - 2007
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DxC4iiaElsuc

An easy way is to only play vinyl.  Since vinyl is the best and all music released on vinyl is good, you're pretty much set if you just buy vinyl house records.  All digital house music is bad, period.

So I usually suck at getting subgenres right so excuse me if I mislabled it, but it's kind of... fidget/electro housish, if I remember correctly.

The hook says something along the lines of, "I find myself in the middle of the dance floor, in the middle of the dance floor, all eyes on me." Also says, "You can dance if you want to." (And no, it's not Safety Dance, thankyouverymuch.) Has a male and female vocal, heavily filtered.

Any clue? Was trying to find it online somewhere to send to a friend. Thanks!

(Yes, I'm still alive.)

Hearts and farts,

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"


 Oof. I'm in the process of introducing my punk rock friend to house so luckily for you I just wrote out a list. He was interested in old school Chicago (e.g. Frankie Knuckles) shit, so I kind of went off of that. It's certainly not comprehensive and I'm sure I forgot some maaajor players (already had to add a few since I first messaged him), but here's what I wrote him, for a start:

Always good to browse here:

http://undergroundhouse.net/

On
that first page is a set by Troydon that is awesome, recorded at my Tonal birthday party a couple years ago. I'm sure I love it as much as I do because of the sentimentality, but I think it's pretty solid aside from that. You can also go
directly to here and search by artist if you sort by artist name: http://www.undergroundhouse.net/mixes/?view=guest_mixes

There
are tons of people I can recommend, but I'll start you off with some of
the classic heavy-hitters below. It's also pretty much all new stuff on UGH, but...

As posted recently, you can also check out old SF House sets here: http://www.thegathering-sf.com/music.html

And more from all over the U.S. here: http://www.ezeskankin.com/

I haven't listened to most of the sets on those two mixtape sites, but classic artists I might suggest:

-DJ Dan
-Doc Martin
-Donal Glaude
-Dutch
-Galen
-Garth
-Halo
-Hipp-E
-Jeno
-John Howard
-Josh Wink
-Mark Farina
-Markie
-Marques Wyatt
-Onionz
-Rick Preston
-Roy Davis Jr
-DJ Sneak
-DJ Spun
-Terry Mullan
-Tony
-Diz
-Sound Republic
-DJ Heather
-Greenskeepers
-Green Velvet/Cajmere (same guy, different aliases)
-Paul Johnson
-Derrick Carter
-Justin Long
-Miss Honey Dijon


 -Joshua (Iz)
-Jt Donaldson
-Raoul Belmans
-Jason Hodges
-Joey Youngman


(***This below was specific to what he was looking for, so I don't know how applicable it is to you, but...***):

You also might want to check out some of Terrence Parker's stuff:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gB78W2Ux_9E&feature=PlayList&p=401B366B2D345905&playnext=1&index=3
http://www.myspace.com/littleetoile and click on the Terrence Parker track I have under my music section

Or Masters at Work (one of my all-time fav fav faaaaav producers):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hgPRwFXi7YQ&feature=related
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YZOFHnSilek

And here is one of my all time classic favs:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yaV3-ebhrMg&feature=related

And another:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zQ5PC54futo

That's all on the more traditional, lighter side of things. The darker, electro, tech, fidget house stuff is also really big right now in SF. Click here and listen to the "bump bump" track for an example:
http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendID=80010187

Or you can go here and stream Galen's latest released set (third down) from New Year's Day Stompy+Sunset party (though of the "dirty" shit, he's still on the lighter, more melodic side of things, which I love). That will give you a good overview of what's popping right now:
http://samurai.fm/bluntedfunk/index.php


For most of the sets you listen to you can go on UGH and then search in the Track ID section to find the name of the record you like. Or if no one's put it up, you can post and ask yourself (e.g. "I'm looking to ID this record: [Artist's name]'s [name of set] mix, at [time in mix when track comes in]."). People are generally pretty helpful.


*phew* Hope that helps! In general, I think the trick
is to pay attention to the records you like, grab the name of the label, then
search more of that label's stuff. You'll probably start to notice
trends in artists and labels that you like best. I'm not a DJ or producer so I'm certainly not the most knowledgeable when it comes to digging for records, but that should give you a start. Good luck! :) 


Lumph,
Alida

I found the CD someone gave me with the mix on it and tracked down the podcast online: http://podcast.freshkidfx.com/2008/12/03/welcome.aspx? The track fully comes in at ~21:00. CLEARLY NOT BRITNEY SPEARS, ANDY.



Here are some more lyrics:



"I woke up this morning, I woke up this morning, I woke up this morning with a splitting, banging headache. What should I do? Now what should I do? You can dance if you want to. You can dance if you want to." *something something Techno* "One hand on a bottle, one hand on a groove. One hand on a bottle, one hand on a groove. You can dance if you want to. You can dance if you want to. You can dance if you want to."

*music*

"I find myself in the middle of a dance floor,  in the middle of a dance floor, all eyes on me, all eyes on me, all eyes on- all eyes on- all eyes on-"

It basically loops parts of the sample again after that. You get the idea.

Thaaaanks.

-Alida

--- On Tue, 3/3/09, littleetoile@aol.com <littleetoile@aol.com> wrote:

> From: littleetoile@aol.com <littleetoile@aol.com>
> Subject: Re: [sfraves]srr: House Tracks?
> To: fable_four@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Date: Tuesday, March 3, 2009, 5:12 PM
> Oof. I'm in the process of introducing my punk rock
> friend to house so luckily for you I just wrote out a list.
> He was interested in old school Chicago (e.g. Frankie
> Knuckles) shit, so I kind of went off of that. It's
> certainly not comprehensive and I'm sure I forgot some
> maaajor players (already had to add a few since I first
> messaged him), but here's what I wrote him, for a start:
> 
> Always good to browse here:
> 
> http://undergroundhouse.net/
> 
> On
> that first page is a set by Troydon that is awesome,
> recorded at my Tonal birthday party a couple years ago.
> I'm sure I love it as much as I do because of the
> sentimentality, but I think it's pretty solid aside from
> that. You can also go
> directly to here and search by artist if you sort by artist
> name:
> http://www.undergroundhouse.net/mixes/?view=guest_mixes
> 
> There
> are tons of people I can recommend, but I'll start you
> off with some of
> the classic heavy-hitters below. It's also pretty much
> all new stuff on UGH, but...
> 
> As posted recently, you can also check out old SF House
> sets here: http://www.thegathering-sf.com/music.html
> 
> And more from all over the U.S. here:
> http://www.ezeskankin.com/
> 
> I haven't listened to most of the sets on those two
> mixtape sites, but classic artists I might suggest:
> 
> -DJ Dan
> -Doc Martin
> -Donal Glaude
> -Dutch
> -Galen
> -Garth
> -Halo
> -Hipp-E
> -Jeno
> -John Howard
> -Josh Wink
> -Mark Farina
> -Markie
> -Marques Wyatt
> -Onionz
> -Rick Preston
> -Roy Davis Jr
> -DJ Sneak
> -DJ Spun
> -Terry Mullan
> -Tony
> -Diz
> -Sound Republic
> -DJ Heather
> -Greenskeepers
> -Green Velvet/Cajmere (same guy, different aliases)
> -Paul Johnson
> -Derrick Carter
> -Justin Long
> -Miss Honey Dijon
> 
> 
>  -Joshua (Iz)
> -Jt Donaldson
> -Raoul Belmans
> -Jason Hodges
> -Joey Youngman
> 
> 
> (***This below was specific to what he was looking for, so
> I don't know how applicable it is to you, but...***):
> 
> You also might want to check out some of Terrence
> Parker's stuff:
> 
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gB78W2Ux_9E&feature=PlayList&p=401B366B2D345905&playnext=1&index=3
> http://www.myspace.com/littleetoile and click on the
> Terrence Parker track I have under my music section
> 
> Or Masters at Work (one of my all-time fav fav faaaaav
> producers):
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hgPRwFXi7YQ&feature=related
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YZOFHnSilek
> 
> And here is one of my all time classic favs:
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yaV3-ebhrMg&feature=related
> 
> And another:
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zQ5PC54futo
> 
> That's all on the more traditional, lighter side of
> things. The darker, electro, tech, fidget house stuff is
> also really big right now in SF. Click here and listen to
> the "bump bump" track for an example:
> http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendID=80010187
> 
> Or you can go here and stream Galen's latest released
> set (third down) from New Year's Day Stompy+Sunset party
> (though of the "dirty" shit, he's still on the
> lighter, more melodic side of things, which I love). That
> will give you a good overview of what's popping right
> now:
> http://samurai.fm/bluntedfunk/index.php
> 
> 
> For most of the sets you listen to you can go on UGH and
> then search in the Track ID section to find the name of the
> record you like. Or if no one's put it up, you can post
> and ask yourself (e.g. "I'm looking to ID this
> record: [Artist's name]'s [name of set] mix, at
> [time in mix when track comes in]."). People are
> generally pretty helpful.
> 
> 
> *phew* Hope that helps! In general, I think the trick
> is to pay attention to the records you like, grab the name
> of the label, then
> search more of that label's stuff. You'll probably
> start to notice
> trends in artists and labels that you like best. I'm
> not a DJ or producer so I'm certainly not the most
> knowledgeable when it comes to digging for records, but that
> should give you a start. Good luck! :) 
> 
> 
> Lumph,
> Alida
> 
> 
> 
> 
>  
>

> music from the bad?  
> I'm sure the first thing that you will ask is what kind
> of house music?  I like

Date: Wed, 4 Mar 2009 08:04:14 -0800 (PST)
From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
To: fable_four@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org, littleetoile@aol.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]srr: House Tracks?


Weren't you originally looking for house labels?

For some of the old school SF flavor, check out some of the old Tweekin' and Panhandle Records releases if you can find them anywhere.  I have a bunch on vinyl...

Also check out Ovum, Dust Traxx, Blockhead, Imperial Dub, older Om records, ... I could go on and on, but I have to run.

BTW, speaking of Imperial Dub, Sunshine Jones (formerly of Dubtribe) is doing some new stuff with a more tech edge that I like a lot.


Peter

--- On Wed, 3/4/09, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

> From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
> Subject: Re: [sfraves]srr: House Tracks?
> To: fable_four@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org, littleetoile@aol.com
> Date: Wednesday, March 4, 2009, 8:04 AM
> Weren't you originally looking for house labels?
> 
> For some of the old school SF flavor, check out some of the
> old Tweekin' and Panhandle Records releases if you can
> find them anywhere.  I have a bunch on vinyl...
> 
> Also check out Ovum, Dust Traxx, Blockhead, Imperial Dub,
> older Om records, ... I could go on and on, but I have to
> run.
> 
> BTW, speaking of Imperial Dub, Sunshine Jones (formerly of
> Dubtribe) is doing some new stuff with a more tech edge that
> I like a lot.
> 
> 
> Peter
> 
> 
> 
>

> --- On Tue, 3/3/09, littleetoile@aol.com
> <littleetoile@aol.com> wrote:
> 
> > From: littleetoile@aol.com
> <littleetoile@aol.com>
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves]srr: House Tracks?
> > To: fable_four@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > Date: Tuesday, March 3, 2009, 5:12 PM
> > Oof. I'm in the process of introducing my punk
> rock
> > friend to house so luckily for you I just wrote out a
> list.
> > He was interested in old school Chicago (e.g. Frankie
> > Knuckles) shit, so I kind of went off of that.
> It's
> > certainly not comprehensive and I'm sure I forgot
> some
> > maaajor players (already had to add a few since I
> first
> > messaged him), but here's what I wrote him, for a
> start:
> > 
> > Always good to browse here:
> > 
> > http://undergroundhouse.net/
> > 
> > On
> > that first page is a set by Troydon that is awesome,
> > recorded at my Tonal birthday party a couple years
> ago.
> > I'm sure I love it as much as I do because of the
> > sentimentality, but I think it's pretty solid
> aside from
> > that. You can also go
> > directly to here and search by artist if you sort by
> artist
> > name:
> >
> http://www.undergroundhouse.net/mixes/?view=guest_mixes
> > 
> > There
> > are tons of people I can recommend, but I'll start
> you
> > off with some of
> > the classic heavy-hitters below. It's also pretty
> much
> > all new stuff on UGH, but...
> > 
> > As posted recently, you can also check out old SF
> House
> > sets here: http://www.thegathering-sf.com/music.html
> > 
> > And more from all over the U.S. here:
> > http://www.ezeskankin.com/
> > 
> > I haven't listened to most of the sets on those
> two
> > mixtape sites, but classic artists I might suggest:
> > 
> > -DJ Dan
> > -Doc Martin
> > -Donal Glaude
> > -Dutch
> > -Galen
> > -Garth
> > -Halo
> > -Hipp-E
> > -Jeno
> > -John Howard
> > -Josh Wink
> > -Mark Farina
> > -Markie
> > -Marques Wyatt
> > -Onionz
> > -Rick Preston
> > -Roy Davis Jr
> > -DJ Sneak
> > -DJ Spun
> > -Terry Mullan
> > -Tony
> > -Diz
> > -Sound Republic
> > -DJ Heather
> > -Greenskeepers
> > -Green Velvet/Cajmere (same guy, different aliases)
> > -Paul Johnson
> > -Derrick Carter
> > -Justin Long
> > -Miss Honey Dijon
> > 
> > 
> >  -Joshua (Iz)
> > -Jt Donaldson
> > -Raoul Belmans
> > -Jason Hodges
> > -Joey Youngman
> > 
> > 
> > (***This below was specific to what he was looking
> for, so
> > I don't know how applicable it is to you,
> but...***):
> > 
> > You also might want to check out some of Terrence
> > Parker's stuff:
> > 
> >
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gB78W2Ux_9E&feature=PlayList&p=401B366B2D345905&playnext=1&index=3
> > http://www.myspace.com/littleetoile and click on the
> > Terrence Parker track I have under my music section
> > 
> > Or Masters at Work (one of my all-time fav fav faaaaav
> > producers):
> >
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hgPRwFXi7YQ&feature=related
> > http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YZOFHnSilek
> > 
> > And here is one of my all time classic favs:
> >
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yaV3-ebhrMg&feature=related
> > 
> > And another:
> > http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zQ5PC54futo
> > 
> > That's all on the more traditional, lighter side
> of
> > things. The darker, electro, tech, fidget house stuff
> is
> > also really big right now in SF. Click here and listen
> to
> > the "bump bump" track for an example:
> >
> http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendID=80010187
> > 
> > Or you can go here and stream Galen's latest
> released
> > set (third down) from New Year's Day Stompy+Sunset
> party
> > (though of the "dirty" shit, he's still
> on the
> > lighter, more melodic side of things, which I love).
> That
> > will give you a good overview of what's popping
> right
> > now:
> > http://samurai.fm/bluntedfunk/index.php
> > 
> > 
> > For most of the sets you listen to you can go on UGH
> and
> > then search in the Track ID section to find the name
> of the
> > record you like. Or if no one's put it up, you can
> post
> > and ask yourself (e.g. "I'm looking to ID
> this
> > record: [Artist's name]'s [name of set] mix,
> at
> > [time in mix when track comes in]."). People are
> > generally pretty helpful.
> > 
> > 
> > *phew* Hope that helps! In general, I think the trick
> > is to pay attention to the records you like, grab the
> name
> > of the label, then
> > search more of that label's stuff. You'll
> probably
> > start to notice
> > trends in artists and labels that you like best.
> I'm
> > not a DJ or producer so I'm certainly not the most
> > knowledgeable when it comes to digging for records,
> but that
> > should give you a start. Good luck! :) 
> > 
> > 
> > Lumph,
> > Alida
> >

--- On Wed, 3/4/09, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

> From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
> Subject: Re: [sfraves]srr: House Tracks?
> To: fable_four@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org, littleetoile@aol.com
> Date: Wednesday, March 4, 2009, 8:04 AM
> Weren't you originally looking for house labels?
> 
> For some of the old school SF flavor, check out some of the
> old Tweekin' and Panhandle Records releases if you can
> find them anywhere.  I have a bunch on vinyl...
> 
> Also check out Ovum, Dust Traxx, Blockhead, Imperial Dub,
> older Om records, ... I could go on and on, but I have to
> run.
> 
> BTW, speaking of Imperial Dub, Sunshine Jones (formerly of
> Dubtribe) is doing some new stuff with a more tech edge that
> I like a lot.
> 
> 
> Peter
> 
> 
> 
>

> --- On Tue, 3/3/09, littleetoile@aol.com
> <littleetoile@aol.com> wrote:
> 
> > From: littleetoile@aol.com
> <littleetoile@aol.com>
> > Subject: Re: [sfraves]srr: House Tracks?
> > To: fable_four@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > Date: Tuesday, March 3, 2009, 5:12 PM
> > Oof. I'm in the process of introducing my punk
> rock
> > friend to house so luckily for you I just wrote out a
> list.
> > He was interested in old school Chicago (e.g. Frankie
> > Knuckles) shit, so I kind of went off of that.
> It's
> > certainly not comprehensive and I'm sure I forgot
> some
> > maaajor players (already had to add a few since I
> first
> > messaged him), but here's what I wrote him, for a
> start:
> > 
> > Always good to browse here:
> > 
> > http://undergroundhouse.net/
> > 
> > On
> > that first page is a set by Troydon that is awesome,
> > recorded at my Tonal birthday party a couple years
> ago.
> > I'm sure I love it as much as I do because of the
> > sentimentality, but I think it's pretty solid
> aside from
> > that. You can also go
> > directly to here and search by artist if you sort by
> artist
> > name:
> >
> http://www.undergroundhouse.net/mixes/?view=guest_mixes
> > 
> > There
> > are tons of people I can recommend, but I'll start
> you
> > off with some of
> > the classic heavy-hitters below. It's also pretty
> much
> > all new stuff on UGH, but...
> > 
> > As posted recently, you can also check out old SF
> House
> > sets here: http://www.thegathering-sf.com/music.html
> > 
> > And more from all over the U.S. here:
> > http://www.ezeskankin.com/
> > 
> > I haven't listened to most of the sets on those
> two
> > mixtape sites, but classic artists I might suggest:
> > 
> > -DJ Dan
> > -Doc Martin
> > -Donal Glaude
> > -Dutch
> > -Galen
> > -Garth
> > -Halo
> > -Hipp-E
> > -Jeno
> > -John Howard
> > -Josh Wink
> > -Mark Farina
> > -Markie
> > -Marques Wyatt
> > -Onionz
> > -Rick Preston
> > -Roy Davis Jr
> > -DJ Sneak
> > -DJ Spun
> > -Terry Mullan
> > -Tony
> > -Diz
> > -Sound Republic
> > -DJ Heather
> > -Greenskeepers
> > -Green Velvet/Cajmere (same guy, different aliases)
> > -Paul Johnson
> > -Derrick Carter
> > -Justin Long
> > -Miss Honey Dijon
> > 
> > 
> >  -Joshua (Iz)
> > -Jt Donaldson
> > -Raoul Belmans
> > -Jason Hodges
> > -Joey Youngman
> > 
> > 
> > (***This below was specific to what he was looking
> for, so
> > I don't know how applicable it is to you,
> but...***):
> > 
> > You also might want to check out some of Terrence
> > Parker's stuff:
> > 
> >
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gB78W2Ux_9E&feature=PlayList&p=401B366B2D345905&playnext=1&index=3
> > http://www.myspace.com/littleetoile and click on the
> > Terrence Parker track I have under my music section
> > 
> > Or Masters at Work (one of my all-time fav fav faaaaav
> > producers):
> >
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hgPRwFXi7YQ&feature=related
> > http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YZOFHnSilek
> > 
> > And here is one of my all time classic favs:
> >
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yaV3-ebhrMg&feature=related
> > 
> > And another:
> > http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zQ5PC54futo
> > 
> > That's all on the more traditional, lighter side
> of
> > things. The darker, electro, tech, fidget house stuff
> is
> > also really big right now in SF. Click here and listen
> to
> > the "bump bump" track for an example:
> >
> http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendID=80010187
> > 
> > Or you can go here and stream Galen's latest
> released
> > set (third down) from New Year's Day Stompy+Sunset
> party
> > (though of the "dirty" shit, he's still
> on the
> > lighter, more melodic side of things, which I love).
> That
> > will give you a good overview of what's popping
> right
> > now:
> > http://samurai.fm/bluntedfunk/index.php
> > 
> > 
> > For most of the sets you listen to you can go on UGH
> and
> > then search in the Track ID section to find the name
> of the
> > record you like. Or if no one's put it up, you can
> post
> > and ask yourself (e.g. "I'm looking to ID
> this
> > record: [Artist's name]'s [name of set] mix,
> at
> > [time in mix when track comes in]."). People are
> > generally pretty helpful.
> > 
> > 
> > *phew* Hope that helps! In general, I think the trick
> > is to pay attention to the records you like, grab the
> name
> > of the label, then
> > search more of that label's stuff. You'll
> probably
> > start to notice
> > trends in artists and labels that you like best.
> I'm
> > not a DJ or producer so I'm certainly not the most
> > knowledgeable when it comes to digging for records,
> but that
> > should give you a start. Good luck! :) 
> > 
> > 
> > Lumph,
> > Alida
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> >

Subject: Re: [sfraves]srr: House Tracks?


Uh, *cough* you could go SFR-core and check out local label Prismatic Tracks:

www.prismatictracks.com

Run by SF stalwart Andrew Phelan, loads of awesome releases, very high standard of quality.  All on Beatport, too.

Full disclosure: I have lots of tracks out on the label.

...but yes, check it out.  Tons of great stuff.

-George

> is

> http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendID=80010187
> >

> released

> party

> right
> > now:
> > http://samurai.fm/bluntedfunk/index.php
> > 
> > 
> > For most of the sets you listen to you can go on UGH
> and
> > then search in the Track ID section to find the name
> of the
> > record you like. Or if no one's put it up, you can
> post
> > and ask yourself (e.g. "I'm looking to ID
> this
> > record: [Artist's name]'s [name of set] mix,
> at
> > [time in mix when track comes in]."). People are
> > generally pretty helpful.
> > 
> > 
> > *phew* Hope that helps! In general, I think the trick
> > is to pay attention to the records you like, grab the
> name
> > of the label, then
> > search more of that label's stuff. You'll
> probably
> > start to notice
> > trends in artists and labels that you like best.
> I'm
> > not a DJ or producer so I'm certainly not the most
> > knowledgeable when it comes to digging for records,
> but that
> > should give you a start. Good luck! :) 
> > 
> > 
> > Lumph,
> > Alida

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From sfraves-return-150342-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Mar 04 20:17:51 2009

Date: Wed, 4 Mar 2009 12:18:03 -0800 (PST)
From: "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>

X-Scanned-By: MIMEDefang 2.56 on 171.66.118.47
X-Greylist: Sender DNS name whitelisted, not delayed by milter-greylist-2.0.2 (kzsu.stanford.edu [127.0.0.1]); Wed, 04 Mar 2009 12:18:09 -0800 (PST)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Tietso smackdown

--0-1839996994-1236197883=:750
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE

Got this from another list.

---------- Forwarded message ----------

From=20the front page of Discogs.com... hilarious:

Latest Music Reviews:

DJ Ti=EBsto - somebedroomdj
I don't know how I even ended up reading the reviews on this page, but
I do know that statements about this freak being the "best dj in the
world, etc. etc." can not be allowed to filter into the collective
consciousness unchallenged. If that were allowed to happen, everything
would fall apart, we would all spontaneously de-evolve, up would
become down, cats would have sex with dogs and rational thought as we
know it would disappear. And I'll be damned if I'm going to contribute
to that happening.

So I just have to say for the record that this.. this thing is nothing
more than a marketing scheme and any claims of him being the best DJ
in the world are patently ludicrous. Music wise, there is nothing new
here. Same old re-hashed formulas and a no talent money machine. This
is not a baseless accusation either, just check the credits on his
productions. When it says "Written/Composed by: XXXX" it means that,
hello, somebody else did all the work. Simple music for simple minded
people who don't want to have to think too hard.

Of course, those of us with a functioning brain already know this. So
the real issue becomes this: what can be done about this wooden shoe
wearing, tulip growing menace?

Simple. I've outlined a few steps you can take to help wage this war:

1) If you hear somebody extolling the virtues of this thing, smack
them casually (but firmly) upside the head and continue the
conversation as if nothing had happened. Pavlov was onto something and
there's no reason why you shouldn't be able to employ this slight
variation of his methods.

2) Though the lion's share of commerce these days is done online,
there are certainly places where this thing's CD's and records are
sold in physical stores. If you ever have occasion to do so at one of
these dens of depravity, you should vomit, urinate, defecate or
otherwise expel your bodily fluid(s) of choice so as to contaminate
every last piece of this thing's merchandise so that the store is
unable to sell it.

3) Organize an event showcasing your favorite type of actual music and
aggressively advertise that the price of admission will be halved for
everyone who brings you one of this thing's CD's, records, t-shirts,
shoes, caps, keychains or any other such nonsense that is branded with
his name or image. Be very careful to wear rubber gloves when handling
the items and throw them all into a gigantic bonfire pit, to be lit at
the culmination of the event.

If we could all employ this 3 pronged attack, I think we could make
some real progress on this.

Now, to the fanboi's. I know your face is probably beet red right
about now and there's a good chance your body is trembling, but I need
you to hear and understand what I'm saying to you. We don't just hate
Tiesto. He's a mere puppet who is a symptom of a larger problem and I
think that anybody who puts him down probably realizes this. It's just
that he has willingly made himself the poster boy for the
commercialization of electronic music and, hence, a big fat target.
There was a time when people actually attended raves and went to hear
music they couldn't hear anywhere else and socialize with other people
who were just as sick of normal society's bullsh*t as they were. They
didn't go to idolize some idiot who was just properly marketed. It was
the music and it moved people. If you support and defend this Asshat,
it is a slap in the face to everybody who comes to this for the right
reasons. Just look at what has happened to every other subculture that
has been co-opted. Hip-hop is a mere shadow of it's former self. Rock
and roll was castrated decades ago and is no longer a viable option
for conveying a real message. Punk has become Emo and is sold at Hot
Topic. Even country music used to have some grit to it, but look at
the saccharine sweet bag of sh*t it is now.

Your hero is just another cog in the giant money machine that music
has been allowed to be reduced to. It's only about money. The fact
that he has to hire engineer's to make his productions for him means
that he is no different than a boy band that has other people write
their songs. If an "artist" isn't making their own art, how can you
put any faith in it? How can you listen to something that they
themselves do not believe in and not feel like you've been played for
a sucker while they laugh at you all the way to the bank?

The bottom line is that there is a lot of different music out there
and lots of genre lines that we create. But what it all comes down to
is that there is music that lies and music that does not lie. Support
music that does not lie, please.




--=20
San Francisco Bay Guardian's Readers Choice Award Winner: Best Radio DJ:
http://www.sfbg.com/promo/pollpositions.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

--0-1839996994-1236197883=:750

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

I thought Andy Warhol put to rest the notion that artists had to actually p=
roduce their art?=A0 And wasn't it Duchamp that finished off the idea that =
art could have value outside of the opinions of an elite that profitted fro=
m manipulating the defnition of same?=0A=0ADon't like Tiesto?=A0 Don't buy =
his music.=0A=0ABut I don't buy into this "he isn't an artist" bullshit.=0A=
=0AHe's an artist of making money by being Tiesto at the very least...=0A=

 a real message. Punk has become Emo and is=0A> sold at Hot=0A> Topic. Even=
 country music used to have some grit to it, but=0A> look at=0A> the saccha=
rine sweet bag of sh*t it is now.=0A> =0A> Your hero is just another cog in=
 the giant money machine=0A> that music=0A> has been allowed to be reduced =
to. It's only about=0A> money. The fact=0A> that he has to hire engineer's =
to make his productions=0A> for him means=0A> that he is no different than =
a boy band that has other=0A> people write=0A> their songs. If an "artist" =
isn't making=0A> their own art, how can you=0A> put any faith in it? How ca=
n you listen to something that=0A> they=0A> themselves do not believe in an=
d not feel like you've=0A> been played for=0A> a sucker while they laugh at=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tietso smackdown

Fair nuff. I just think making blanket statements about being "the
best" dj in the world are bs. That's purely relative and depends on
genre.

We can all agree that he's a giant douche though.

On 3/4/09, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

>> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
>>
>> From the front page of Discogs.com... hilarious:
>>
>> Latest Music Reviews:
>>
>> DJ Ti=EBsto - somebedroomdj
>> I don't know how I even ended up reading the reviews on
>> this page, but
>> I do know that statements about this freak being the
>> "best dj in the
>> world, etc. etc." can not be allowed to filter into
>> the collective
>> consciousness unchallenged. If that were allowed to happen,
>> everything
>> would fall apart, we would all spontaneously de-evolve, up
>> would
>> become down, cats would have sex with dogs and rational
>> thought as we
>> know it would disappear. And I'll be damned if I'm
>> going to contribute
>> to that happening.
>>
>> So I just have to say for the record that this.. this thing
>> is nothing
>> more than a marketing scheme and any claims of him being
>> the best DJ
>> in the world are patently ludicrous. Music wise, there is
>> nothing new
>> here. Same old re-hashed formulas and a no talent money
>> machine. This
>> is not a baseless accusation either, just check the credits
>> on his
>> productions. When it says "Written/Composed by:
>> XXXX" it means that,
>> hello, somebody else did all the work. Simple music for
>> simple minded
>> people who don't want to have to think too hard.
>>
>> Of course, those of us with a functioning brain already
>> know this. So
>> the real issue becomes this: what can be done about this
>> wooden shoe
>> wearing, tulip growing menace?
>>
>> Simple. I've outlined a few steps you can take to help
>> wage this war:
>>
>> 1) If you hear somebody extolling the virtues of this
>> thing, smack
>> them casually (but firmly) upside the head and continue the
>> conversation as if nothing had happened. Pavlov was onto
>> something and
>> there's no reason why you shouldn't be able to
>> employ this slight
>> variation of his methods.
>>
>> 2) Though the lion's share of commerce these days is
>> done online,
>> there are certainly places where this thing's CD's
>> and records are
>> sold in physical stores. If you ever have occasion to do so
>> at one of
>> these dens of depravity, you should vomit, urinate,
>> defecate or
>> otherwise expel your bodily fluid(s) of choice so as to
>> contaminate
>> every last piece of this thing's merchandise so that
>> the store is
>> unable to sell it.
>>
>> 3) Organize an event showcasing your favorite type of
>> actual music and
>> aggressively advertise that the price of admission will be
>> halved for
>> everyone who brings you one of this thing's CD's,
>> records, t-shirts,
>> shoes, caps, keychains or any other such nonsense that is
>> branded with
>> his name or image. Be very careful to wear rubber gloves
>> when handling
>> the items and throw them all into a gigantic bonfire pit,
>> to be lit at
>> the culmination of the event.
>>
>> If we could all employ this 3 pronged attack, I think we
>> could make
>> some real progress on this.
>>
>> Now, to the fanboi's. I know your face is probably beet
>> red right
>> about now and there's a good chance your body is
>> trembling, but I need
>> you to hear and understand what I'm saying to you. We
>> don't just hate
>> Tiesto. He's a mere puppet who is a symptom of a larger
>> problem and I
>> think that anybody who puts him down probably realizes
>> this. It's just
>> that he has willingly made himself the poster boy for the
>> commercialization of electronic music and, hence, a big fat
>> target.
>> There was a time when people actually attended raves and
>> went to hear
>> music they couldn't hear anywhere else and socialize
>> with other people
>> who were just as sick of normal society's bullsh*t as
>> they were. They
>> didn't go to idolize some idiot who was just properly
>> marketed. It was
>> the music and it moved people. If you support and defend
>> this Asshat,
>> it is a slap in the face to everybody who comes to this for
>> the right
>> reasons. Just look at what has happened to every other
>> subculture that
>> has been co-opted. Hip-hop is a mere shadow of it's
>> former self. Rock
>> and roll was castrated decades ago and is no longer a
>> viable option
>> for conveying a real message. Punk has become Emo and is
>> sold at Hot
>> Topic. Even country music used to have some grit to it, but
>> look at
>> the saccharine sweet bag of sh*t it is now.
>>
>> Your hero is just another cog in the giant money machine
>> that music
>> has been allowed to be reduced to. It's only about
>> money. The fact
>> that he has to hire engineer's to make his productions
>> for him means
>> that he is no different than a boy band that has other
>> people write
>> their songs. If an "artist" isn't making
>> their own art, how can you
>> put any faith in it? How can you listen to something that
>> they
>> themselves do not believe in and not feel like you've
>> been played for
>> a sucker while they laugh at you all the way to the bank?
>>
>> The bottom line is that there is a lot of different music
>> out there
>> and lots of genre lines that we create. But what it all
>> comes down to
>> is that there is music that lies and music that does not
>> lie. Support
>> music that does not lie, please.
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> -- San Francisco Bay Guardian's Readers Choice Award
>> Winner: Best Radio DJ:

Subject: [sfraves] BREAKING - Albany Takes Step to Repeal Rockefeller Drug Laws

--0016e64ec90a5dd0c0046453b3fa
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

March 5, 2009
 Albany Takes Step to Repeal Rockefeller Drug Laws By JEREMY W.
PETERS<http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/p/jeremy_=
w_peters/index.html?inline=3Dnyt-per>

ALBANY =E2=80=94 The state legislature took pivotal steps on Wednesday towa=
rd
repealing much of what remains of the state=E2=80=99s 1970s-era drug laws, =
which
have tied judges hands and imposed mandatory prison terms for many
nonviolent drug offenses.

The Assembly approved by a 96-46 vote legislation that would restore judges=
=E2=80=99
discretion in sentencing lower level drug offenders by removing laws that
require a prosecutor=E2=80=99s consent before judges can send someone to a =
drug
treatment program. Debate on the bill got underway late Wednesday afternoon=
.

The same bill was introduced on Wednesday in the Senate, where Democratic
leaders vowed to quickly take it up. But the task now confronting
legislative leaders and Gov. David A.
Paterson<http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/p/david=
_a_paterson/index.html?inline=3Dnyt-per>is
to reconcile the Assembly bill =E2=80=94 which is considered the most
far-reaching of the proposals on the table now =E2=80=94 with the governor=
=E2=80=99s plan
and the bill that Senate Democrats write.

Drug law reform has for years been one of the most divisive social issues
debated in Albany. Bills aimed at broadly overhauling the statutes, known a=
s
the Rockefeller drug laws because former Gov. Nelson A.
Rockefeller<http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/r/ne=
lson_aldrich_rockefeller/index.html?inline=3Dnyt-per>championed
their approval, have routinely passed the Democratic-controlled
Assembly over the years, only to die in the Senate, which until this year
was run by Republicans.

With Democrats now in the majority in the Senate and Mr. Paterson an avowed
Rockefeller reform advocate, supporters of rewriting the drug laws see this
year as their best chance to pass a plan that essentially does away with
mandatory sentences for drug crimes.

=E2=80=9CI think the stars are aligned,=E2=80=9D Sheldon
Silver<http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/sheldon=
_silver/index.html?inline=3Dnyt-per>,
the speaker of the Assembly, said at a news conference on Wednesday morning=
.
=E2=80=9CIt=E2=80=99s time has come.=E2=80=9D

Senate Democrats were debating the issue in a closed-door conference on
Wednesday night.

But before any three-way compromise is reached, several sticking points nee=
d
to be resolved. Those issues include whether drug offenders who do not
complete treatment would be sent to prison and whether offenders would firs=
t
need to be certified as addicted before they could enter a treatment
program.

The State Legislature has already eliminated the stiffest provisions of the
Rockefeller laws, doing away in 2004 with life sentences for drug crimes an=
d
reducing other penalties for the most serious offenses. But supporters of
the Assembly plan believe that plan is an opportunity to finish what began
in 2004.

=E2=80=9CIt should not have taken this state 36 years to realize that manda=
tory
sentences are a one-size-fits-all approach,=E2=80=9D Mr. Silver said. =E2=
=80=9CWe cannot
wait another year.=E2=80=9DDrug law reform activists said that the legislat=
ion would
be an opportunity for New York to catch up after falling behind other state=
s
that have greatly expanded their drug treatment programs as alternatives to
prison.

=E2=80=9CThe general theme is states are making greater effort to divert pe=
ople into
treatment programs, and they=E2=80=99re start to use prison not as a first =
resort
but a secondary or last resort,=E2=80=9D said Gabriel Sayegh, the director =
of
organizing and policy for the Drug Policy Alliance Network, a national drug
law reform group.

=E2=80=9CIf the legislature follows through with moving toward a public hea=
lth
approach, New York could potentially go from having some of the worst laws
in the country to having some of the best.=E2=80=9D

But district attorneys have expressed concern that the proposals currently
being considered in Albany strip them of their important function as a chec=
k
against judges.

=E2=80=9CWe=E2=80=99ve achieved a balance where we=E2=80=99ve preserved pub=
lic safety and reduced
our prison population,=E2=80=9D said Michael C. Green, the district attorne=
y for
Monroe County. =E2=80=9CI look at that and say why do we want to take this =
system
and make a seismic shift? My fear is that you=E2=80=99re going to disturb o=
ne of
those trends.=E2=80=9D


--=20
Nyc Labrets

Harper Lee, 2006

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tietso smackdown

think that artists have had other paint for them since forever. before 
michelangelo buonorotti painted the entire sistine chapel by himself, he 
had kicked out the many people helping him on the scaffold cause they 
kept on messing it up. the flemish masters often taught their skills to 
others and more paintings are often attributed to the masters than the 
ones they actually painted. klf didn't make much of their own music 
either. they just had the good sense to know what worked.

sean.

>> From the front page of Discogs.com... hilarious:
>>
>> Latest Music Reviews:
>>
>> DJ Tiësto - somebedroomdj
>> I don't know how I even ended up reading the reviews on
>> this page, but
>> I do know that statements about this freak being the
>> "best dj in the
>> world, etc. etc." can not be allowed to filter into
>> the collective
>> consciousness unchallenged. If that were allowed to happen,
>> everything
>> would fall apart, we would all spontaneously de-evolve, up
>> would
>> become down, cats would have sex with dogs and rational
>> thought as we
>> know it would disappear. And I'll be damned if I'm
>> going to contribute
>> to that happening.
>>
>> So I just have to say for the record that this.. this thing
>> is nothing
>> more than a marketing scheme and any claims of him being
>> the best DJ
>> in the world are patently ludicrous. Music wise, there is
>> nothing new
>> here. Same old re-hashed formulas and a no talent money
>> machine. This
>> is not a baseless accusation either, just check the credits
>> on his
>> productions. When it says "Written/Composed by:
>> XXXX" it means that,
>> hello, somebody else did all the work. Simple music for
>> simple minded
>> people who don't want to have to think too hard.
>>
>> Of course, those of us with a functioning brain already
>> know this. So
>> the real issue becomes this: what can be done about this
>> wooden shoe
>> wearing, tulip growing menace?
>>
>> Simple. I've outlined a few steps you can take to help
>> wage this war:
>>
>> 1) If you hear somebody extolling the virtues of this
>> thing, smack
>> them casually (but firmly) upside the head and continue the
>> conversation as if nothing had happened. Pavlov was onto
>> something and
>> there's no reason why you shouldn't be able to
>> employ this slight
>> variation of his methods.
>>
>> 2) Though the lion's share of commerce these days is
>> done online,
>> there are certainly places where this thing's CD's
>> and records are
>> sold in physical stores. If you ever have occasion to do so
>> at one of
>> these dens of depravity, you should vomit, urinate,
>> defecate or
>> otherwise expel your bodily fluid(s) of choice so as to
>> contaminate
>> every last piece of this thing's merchandise so that
>> the store is
>> unable to sell it.
>>
>> 3) Organize an event showcasing your favorite type of
>> actual music and
>> aggressively advertise that the price of admission will be
>> halved for
>> everyone who brings you one of this thing's CD's,
>> records, t-shirts,
>> shoes, caps, keychains or any other such nonsense that is
>> branded with
>> his name or image. Be very careful to wear rubber gloves
>> when handling
>> the items and throw them all into a gigantic bonfire pit,
>> to be lit at
>> the culmination of the event.
>>
>> If we could all employ this 3 pronged attack, I think we
>> could make
>> some real progress on this.
>>
>> Now, to the fanboi's. I know your face is probably beet
>> red right
>> about now and there's a good chance your body is
>> trembling, but I need
>> you to hear and understand what I'm saying to you. We
>> don't just hate
>> Tiesto. He's a mere puppet who is a symptom of a larger
>> problem and I
>> think that anybody who puts him down probably realizes
>> this. It's just
>> that he has willingly made himself the poster boy for the
>> commercialization of electronic music and, hence, a big fat
>> target.
>> There was a time when people actually attended raves and
>> went to hear
>> music they couldn't hear anywhere else and socialize
>> with other people
>> who were just as sick of normal society's bullsh*t as
>> they were. They
>> didn't go to idolize some idiot who was just properly
>> marketed. It was
>> the music and it moved people. If you support and defend
>> this Asshat,
>> it is a slap in the face to everybody who comes to this for
>> the right
>> reasons. Just look at what has happened to every other
>> subculture that
>> has been co-opted. Hip-hop is a mere shadow of it's
>> former self. Rock
>> and roll was castrated decades ago and is no longer a
>> viable option
>> for conveying a real message. Punk has become Emo and is
>> sold at Hot
>> Topic. Even country music used to have some grit to it, but
>> look at
>> the saccharine sweet bag of sh*t it is now.
>>
>> Your hero is just another cog in the giant money machine
>> that music
>> has been allowed to be reduced to. It's only about
>> money. The fact
>> that he has to hire engineer's to make his productions
>> for him means
>> that he is no different than a boy band that has other
>> people write
>> their songs. If an "artist" isn't making
>> their own art, how can you
>> put any faith in it? How can you listen to something that
>> they
>> themselves do not believe in and not feel like you've
>> been played for
>> a sucker while they laugh at you all the way to the bank?
>>
>> The bottom line is that there is a lot of different music
>> out there
>> and lots of genre lines that we create. But what it all
>> comes down to
>> is that there is music that lies and music that does not
>> lie. Support
>> music that does not lie, please.
>>
>>
>>
>>

> punk
> > rock
> > > friend to house so luckily for you I just wrote
> out a
> > list.
> > > He was interested in old school Chicago (e.g.
> Frankie
> > > Knuckles) shit, so I kind of went off of that.
> > It's
> > > certainly not comprehensive and I'm sure I
> forgot
> > some
> > > maaajor players (already had to add a few since I
> > first
> > > messaged him), but here's what I wrote him,
> for a
> > start:
> > > 
> > > Always good to browse here:
> > > 
> > > http://undergroundhouse.net/
> > > 
> > > On
> > > that first page is a set by Troydon that is
> awesome,
> > > recorded at my Tonal birthday party a couple
> years
> > ago.
> > > I'm sure I love it as much as I do because of
> the
> > > sentimentality, but I think it's pretty solid
> > aside from
> > > that. You can also go
> > > directly to here and search by artist if you sort
> by
> > artist
> > > name:
> > >
> >
> http://www.undergroundhouse.net/mixes/?view=guest_mixes
> > > 
> > > There
> > > are tons of people I can recommend, but I'll
> start
> > you
> > > off with some of
> > > the classic heavy-hitters below. It's also
> pretty
> > much
> > > all new stuff on UGH, but...
> > > 
> > > As posted recently, you can also check out old SF
> > House
> > > sets here:
> http://www.thegathering-sf.com/music.html
> > > 
> > > And more from all over the U.S. here:
> > > http://www.ezeskankin.com/
> > > 
> > > I haven't listened to most of the sets on
> those
> > two
> > > mixtape sites, but classic artists I might
> suggest:
> > > 
> > > -DJ Dan
> > > -Doc Martin
> > > -Donal Glaude
> > > -Dutch
> > > -Galen
> > > -Garth
> > > -Halo
> > > -Hipp-E
> > > -Jeno
> > > -John Howard
> > > -Josh Wink
> > > -Mark Farina
> > > -Markie
> > > -Marques Wyatt
> > > -Onionz
> > > -Rick Preston
> > > -Roy Davis Jr
> > > -DJ Sneak
> > > -DJ Spun
> > > -Terry Mullan
> > > -Tony
> > > -Diz
> > > -Sound Republic
> > > -DJ Heather
> > > -Greenskeepers
> > > -Green Velvet/Cajmere (same guy, different
> aliases)
> > > -Paul Johnson
> > > -Derrick Carter
> > > -Justin Long
> > > -Miss Honey Dijon
> > > 
> > > 
> > >  -Joshua (Iz)
> > > -Jt Donaldson
> > > -Raoul Belmans
> > > -Jason Hodges
> > > -Joey Youngman
> > > 
> > > 
> > > (***This below was specific to what he was
> looking
> > for, so
> > > I don't know how applicable it is to you,
> > but...***):
> > > 
> > > You also might want to check out some of Terrence
> > > Parker's stuff:
> > > 
> > >
> >
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gB78W2Ux_9E&feature=PlayList&p=401B366B2D345905&playnext=1&index=3
> > > http://www.myspace.com/littleetoile and click on
> the
> > > Terrence Parker track I have under my music
> section
> > > 
> > > Or Masters at Work (one of my all-time fav fav
> faaaaav
> > > producers):
> > >
> >
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hgPRwFXi7YQ&feature=related
> > > http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YZOFHnSilek
> > > 
> > > And here is one of my all time classic favs:
> > >
> >
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yaV3-ebhrMg&feature=related
> > > 
> > > And another:
> > > http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zQ5PC54futo
> > > 
> > > That's all on the more traditional, lighter
> side
> > of
> > > things. The darker, electro, tech, fidget house
> stuff
> > is
> > > also really big right now in SF. Click here and
> listen
> > to
> > > the "bump bump" track for an example:
> > >
> >
> http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendID=80010187
> > > 
> > > Or you can go here and stream Galen's latest
> > released
> > > set (third down) from New Year's Day
> Stompy+Sunset
> > party
> > > (though of the "dirty" shit, he's
> still
> > on the
> > > lighter, more melodic side of things, which I
> love).
> > That
> > > will give you a good overview of what's
> popping
> > right
> > > now:
> > > http://samurai.fm/bluntedfunk/index.php
> > > 
> > > 
> > > For most of the sets you listen to you can go on
> UGH
> > and
> > > then search in the Track ID section to find the
> name
> > of the
> > > record you like. Or if no one's put it up,
> you can
> > post
> > > and ask yourself (e.g. "I'm looking to
> ID
> > this
> > > record: [Artist's name]'s [name of set]
> mix,
> > at
> > > [time in mix when track comes in]."). People
> are
> > > generally pretty helpful.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > *phew* Hope that helps! In general, I think the
> trick
> > > is to pay attention to the records you like, grab
> the
> > name
> > > of the label, then
> > > search more of that label's stuff. You'll
> > probably
> > > start to notice
> > > trends in artists and labels that you like best.
> > I'm
> > > not a DJ or producer so I'm certainly not the
> most
> > > knowledgeable when it comes to digging for
> records,
> > but that
> > > should give you a start. Good luck! :) 
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Lumph,
> > > Alida
> > > 
> > > 
> > > 
> > >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: update..

i had my truck repo'd voluntarily. possibly like you have now. depending 
on what they sell it for at auction you are still legally required to 
pay back your loan even though you don't own the m'f'n vehicle. like 
they expect you to give up the car cause you can't pay for it then they 
expect you to still pay for it. it doesn't make sense. but the truth is 
that legally they can sue for you to repay the loan but they usually 
don't go that far. they just harass you continually till they think you 
will break. if they do start to leave messages with lawyers and letters. 
talk to a bankruptcy lawyer. but you should attempt to pay back what you 
owe if the vehicle is the only thing wrong on your credit history and 
you can afford to refinance it.

my advice get yourself a beater car like a toyota from 2005 and pay off 
your loan.

sean.

Wow. We are all really, REALLY excited about this show, folks.

Perhaps not out BIGGEST lineup to date, but without a doubt one of the BEST
we've ever had.

Fans of Steve Bug will definitely love his parter in the Poker Flat nights,
MARTIN LANDSKY, making his Endup debut. Get ready for an extended set of
sexy and sophisticated minimal house and techno from one of the world's
finest!

Warming things up for Martin we have another favorite of ours, AUDIO WERNER=
,
doing a rare LIVE performance. We could try to explain why we've wanted to
bring him over for so long, but trust us, you'll have much more fun finding
out for yourselves!

Since Daylight Savings Time ends tomorrow night, we lose an hour at 2am. Du=
e
to the slightly shorter show, things will get going early, with Audio Werne=
r
taking the stage @ 12:30am.  Heck, come down before 11pm, hear some great
music, and get in FREE!

Rest up and eat your Wheaties. This is gonna be a hot one. :)


----> Greg, Craig, Alland, Sammy, and Nikola

___________________________________________



Saturday, March 7th, 2009

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant house
every 1st Saturday at The Endup



featuring from Berlin:


MARTIN LANDSKY

(Poker Flat . Dessous . Intim)

Martin Landsky is without a doubt one of the most revered
and sought-after names in underground dance music today.
In addition to running the Poker Flat Nights with Steve Bug
and producing for several ace labels including his own Intim,
his skills behind the decks (including exalted performances
at last year's WMC and DEMF) have raised his profile to
near legendary proportions.  Prepare for a night of sexy and
artful house and techno, paired with the impeccable
programming and flawless mixing Martin has come to be
known for the world over.



and from Cologne:


AUDIO WERNER - LIVE

(Perlon . Hartchef Discos. Hello?Repeat . Ware)
(Circus Company. Trapez . Musique Risqu=E9e)

Audio Werner first caught our ears and won our hearts at
2006's DEMF, where his jaw-dropping live PA stole the
show at the Get Perlonized afterparty. His highly creative,
technically masterful, and relentlessly funky productions
have established a benchmark of quality strived for by
musicians around the globe.  We've wanted to bring him
over for years, and are truly honored to now present a rare
live performance of brand new material by one of our
favorite artists in his SF debut.



with [KONTROL] residents:


CRAIG KUNA  (Platform . ESDJCO)
http://www.myspace.com/craig1

ALLAND BYALLO  (Nightlight . Auralism . Leibe*Detail)
http://www.myspace.com/alland

SAMMY D  (Classic . Dirtybird . Utensil)
http://www.myspace.com/sammydoyle

NIKOLA BAYTALA  (S.W.A.T. . Robsoul . Junior Boys Own)
http://www.myspace.com/nikolaswat


Set times:

1000-1050  Nikola Baytala
1050-1140  Alland Byallo
1140-1230  Craig Kuna
1230-0200  Audio Werner (live)
(clocks jump forward 1 hour)
0300-0510  Martin Landsky
0510-0600  Sammy D
