___________________________________________________


MARTIN LANDSKY

Unlike any other German protagonist of the electronic dance scene, Martin
Landsky withdrew himself from the well known category of  electronic dance
music. The verbal approach is of course only a portion of the complete and
original sound of Landsky=91s music which combines Techno, House, Minimal a=
nd
Funk. He has been creating waves as a sensational DJ and producer since the
mid-90's and Landsky has also been heard and recognized since 2000 as one o=
f
the key figures in the circle of producers at Poker Flat Recordings. The
label owner Steve Bug is also a long term friend of Landsky.

"As a DJ and as musician I try to balance between both traditional House an=
d
Techno music. Despite the fact that I use a lot of reduction for that
electronic sound, it is my duty to create deep music which must also always
include twisty and funky elements=93 says Martin. With confidant mixing fro=
m
retrostyle roots to up-to-date Club music, this all but consequently
represents Landsky like hardly any other musician and DJ of the Poker Flat
Style.

The special affinity to the roots of black club music fell in Landsky=91s
sight early on in his life. Through his hobby of breakdancing as an eleven
year old boy, Martin Landsky aquired an impulsive contact to dance music,
from funk to hiphop.  Starting initially on a tapedeck and then later on hi=
s
fathers Bontempi organ, as well as a pitch control record player, it was
clear to see from the first single megamixes he produced that he had lost
his heart hopelessly to the music.

In the beginning DJing was always the most important thing for Landsky=91s
musical identity. He was just fourteen when he first started to perform at
school celebrations  and private parties. Of course the ultimate moment of
his musical carrier came around when he first visited Hamburg=91s Kultclub
Front in 1988. The mixture of Funk and the growing trend of House, Acid and
Techno electrified Landsky like nothing else before and has affected his
musical aesthetics up untill the present day..  In 1994 his hard work and
persistance payed off and his dream came true when he was offered a regular
residency at his favourite club.

It soon became clear that Landsky would not last the duration as just an
exclusive and shining local heroic DJ and so then started to work for the
newly established distribution department of Container Records. He then
later worked for the distribution company Word and Sound, and it was throug=
h
both of these jobs that he gained valuable contacts which helped him to
travel much further afield as a DJ. At the end of 1999 he made a last and
final decision to leave Hamburg and try his luck in Berlin as a full time D=
J
and Musician. With the help of regular Bookings and his friends Cl=E9 and
Steve Bug, he helped to arrange a series of "Poker Flat Nights" at famous
"Sternradio" and regular headliner bookings in some of the most renowned
clubs in Berlin such as E-Werk, the Pfefferbank, Tresor and Casino. He also
put together many Mix CD=91s for labels such as Poker Flat, Systematic and =
the
Partysan complilation series which turned Landsky into one of the most
important figures in the German Club sound of the year 2000.

Parallel to this and as a result of his music productions, Landsky gained
the status as one of the most important protagonists with a slightly
different understanding of house music. Two years after Martin Landsky=91s
first release in 1995 called "Sampled House Vol. 1" for Container Records,
he then announced the release of his first 12" the "Horner Corner EP" in
1997 under the name of Pseudonym 'City Nord' on the London label MC
Projects. From this point on Landsky=91s definition of House music became
internationally known.

The following year Martin released his 12=93 "My Hidden Basement" which was
the starting point of his first new label=82 Effortil Records, then came
"Love-Fourty" which was the second release to appear in 1999. His label, no=
w
under the name of Intim Recordings and of course his first releases for
Dessous ("Wild EP") and Poker Flat ("Crude Clay"), made him acquainted for
the first time within a big circle of renown DJ=91s and producers. Still, i=
n
the year 2000 he began working on his first longplayer for Poker Flat
Records, which in the following year brought his status up to an
international level.

"In Between"  was the title of Landskys debut album which was directly
linked to his third Intim-EP "Follow Me" and the Poker Flat Records 12"
release "Sweet Sweet Morning". The year 2001 was the most productive and
successful year in Landsky=91s career.

In the Summer of 2003 Landsky had reached a new point in his understanding
of House music. On "Reject" he worked together intensively with Filip G., a=
n
amazing vocalist from Hamburg. Not least because of the catchy vocals, the
single became a massive global club hit which lasted for weeks in the Germa=
n
club charts and which also landed Landsky into the playlists of some of the
hippest DJs around. There was also Landsky=91s remix of the single "The
Difference" by DK7 which was played to extent up and down the clubs
worldwide.

Besides the remixes (for D.H.S., Marc Romboy, Booka Shade, Eyerer &
Chopstick or Namito) In the past, Landsky recently created  some special
moments for club nights with the hits "Fools (They Don't Know The Time)"
from 2004, "FM Safari" (2005) and last but not least "1000 Miles" (2006), a
dusky hypnotic masterpiece which is without a doubt Landsky=91s most
successful piece of work. More recently "Let me Dance" was the next track t=
o
follow up in the footsteps of "1000 Miles".


*** Resident Advisor on Landsky's return to NYC:

"Does Martin Landsky play the sexiest techno in the business? After blow-up
sets in Miami and Detroit last year coupled with a devastating afterhours
performance at Rebel for Sunday School for Degenerates New York, Martin
returns for a follow-up lesson in house, techno, with hints of acid. The
Intim label headmaster puts together a portfolio with everything from
flawless mixing to sexy vocals that shows why he is hailed as one of the to=
p
DJs in the upper class of the Techno community."


=3D=3D=3D> LINKS:

http://www.landsky.de/

Martin Landsky's discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/martin%20landsky

http://www.myspace.com/mlandsky

__________________________________________________________________


AUDIO WERNER

Andreas Werner is one of today's most prolific figures in the incredible
techno universe of Cologne. He encapsulates a delicate rhythmic sound and
expression that is best exemplified in his 12=94 'Zwrtshak Drive'=97a favor=
ite
among artists such as Guido Schneider, Richie Hawtin and Ricardo Villalobos=
.
It was also a #1 selection in the German publication Groove Magazine.

Supported in recent years by Triple R (head of the Traum label) under his
pseudonym Audio Werner, Andreas has developed a sound that has renewed and
continued the refined techno tradition in Cologne=97the flagship European c=
ity
for electronic music over the last decade.

Audio Werner has had releases on Perlon, Hello?Repeat, Traum, Trapez, Moon
Harbour, Ware, and his own Hartchef Discos, disseminating his meticulous
works that today still reveal many fresh nuances. His sound is part of a
genre that the Germans gravitate to consistently and not without palpable
success, especially considering the adversity towards decadent raves in
recent memory.

Both contemplative and functional, his musical style is a voice for artisti=
c
minimalism in Cologne and serves as a reference for the entire internationa=
l
scene.


=3D=3D=3D> LINKS:

http://www.hartchef.de

Audio Werner's discography
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Audio%20Werner

http://www.myspace.com/audiowerner

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DvKFOnDH--dU

Subject: [sfraves] My Wed night Review

So I managed to get out on Wed night, hoping the public transportation =20
gods & goddesses would be nice to me & let me watch Easy Street =20
perform... I mean... I got to the City by approx. like 7:45-ish, ate =20
some dinner, well.. i got off @ the wrong stop... i shulda got off =20
Civiv & 8th, but got off Powell... so the walk after dinner from SF =20
Centre to The Stud was kinda long... oh well... i got there & like =20
yaaaaaaaay... i saw Chel-C!!!!  We talked, I watched her set up, i saw =20
her look a goth girlie during their sound check under like this red =20
light, I saw them perform 1 song during sound check, man... that =20
vocoder stuff that Chel-C does is just so yummy... Travis' vocals were =20
sooo good to, I mean, he kinda went flat sometimes during sound check, =20
but man, his energy on stage is just Awesome!!!

So it was fun hangin' out there & just catching up, met a few new =20
people.. unfortunately, I had to duck out around 10PM-ish 'cause =20
well... had to catch 1 of the last buses that went to Hercules from El =20
Cerrito Del Norte... I mean... after reading the debut of their new =20
song in Chel-C's last post, I kinda felt bad I couldn't stay longer... =20
but hopefully I was able to show support by being there early... but =20
there are more Easy Street performances to come & I can't wait to =20
fully be there for those... YAAAAY

I mean.. it was a good night to be out of suberbia 'cause well, it =20
hasn't rained all day & it was just nice bein' in the city.. ok.. so =20
like by the time i got to hercules... like I usually call home for =20
someone to get me @ the gas station... so when i was @ the gas =20
station, i called & that recorded voice "the number you are trying to =20
reach" yada yada yada was on instead of singing... well... by the time =20
i got to hercules, it was like kinda hardcore pouring rain, so i =20
figured that the node where all teh comcast power comes from was =20
fucked again or something... so i just kinda kicked it @ the gas =20
station & talked to my Uncle who works graveyard there, then this dude =20
& this lady walk in & either bough 5 calling cards or 5 lotto =20
tickets... the guy turned around to me said HI to me...

"Are you OK?" he asked me.

"I'm alright I guess, I mean like, I'm hella tryin' to call home & the =20
phone's diconnected or something, I'm guessin' 'cause of the rain, & I =20
have no way to get home unless I walk which would be kinda hardcore to =20
do right now," I replied.

"So you need a ride home?  Where do you live?" he asked.

"Ummm, well... like kinda down the street, down refugio passed the big =20
circle," I said.

"Oh, that's not far, I can give you a ride home! That wouldn't be a =20
problem at all!" he said.

"Holy Shit, are you fuckin' serious??  That fuckin' Rocks man... Thank =20
You soo much!" I said.

"No problem," he said with a giggle then turned back to his friend to =20
take care of them lotto tickets or calling cards.

So I followed them back to their car & got in... there was this other =20
dude in the driver's seat... the lady got in the back, sat down, & =20
suggested we all pray.. lol... Hello 2day... so I bowed my head while =20
we all prayed.. shortly after, she got her stuff & left...

 From Shell to my house, the rain started pouring harder, but oh my =20
goodness man, Thank God I was in a car getting a ride & not walking =20
(no pun intended)... on the way to my house, the guys told me how they =20
were youth ministers, we had some Bible talk, & I told them about my =20
recent loses.. by the time we got to my house, they felt a need to =20
pray again, so for a few minutes, we prayed... again.. lol... then =20
they told me about their weekly Bible Study prayer meetings & invited =20
me, which I thought sounded like a good idea since I haven't really =20
fellowshipped in a while or visited that part of my life in a while, =20
so yeah, why not.. lol...

But yeah man... that was kinda intense... all in all, it was an =20
interesting night :)  I mean.. mondo point being, yes, I did see Easy =20
Street, although it was just 1 song, & it was during sound check, but =20
yummy chooange, singing, & overall 2 thumbs up :)

Peace=3D->
Just Me=3D->
Osby {8O)



---------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: TONIGHT!! 3/7 - Flaming Lotus Girls' Serpent Mother - FREE


The Flaming Lotus Girls and The Ambient Mafia present:
SERPENT MOTHER ART RECEPTION  *  TONIGHT, 03.07.09

Tonight, on Saturday March 7th, the Serpent will light up the Bay in an art=
 opening gala reception from 7.00PM-midnight.

There has never been a sculpture like the Serpent Mother. The warmth of her=
 embrace and her coiling design create an atmospheric space in which over a=
 thousand people can stand. Her 168=E2=80=99 long stainless steel spine coi=
ls around the massive space, while her 20=E2=80=99 long neck and head tower=
 over her audience. The audience takes control, however, by directing her m=
ovement, raising her hydraulically- actuated neck and opening her fanged mo=
uth. Full audience participation makes each installation a singular experie=
nce =E2=80=93 come make it happen.

This magnificent installation of a 168' skeletal stainless steel snake will=
 be on display Saturday March 7th, on Treasure Island. We will open the Ser=
pent for a gallery opening from 7 pm until midnight. We hope you will join =
us for this fun and free event.

Music provided by The Ambient Mafia:
olde nasty vs. peek nasty
the captain vs. harken
shane
mino
redstickman

About the FLG:
The Flaming Lotus Girls are a female-driven group of metal artists who desi=
gn and construct kinetic, mechanical fire art. Our mission is to create mon=
umental works of interactive art through a collaborative process. Our visio=
n is to empower women to learn new skills and become experienced, talented =
and active artists in their own right.

Our work =E2=80=93 a combination of sculptural arts, kinetics, robotics, el=
ectronics, and fire engineering - is designed collaboratively; made collabo=
ratively.

We create interactive large-scale fire installations that engages viewers a=
nd invite them to become part of the art.

TONIGHT!! 3/7/09
7pm - Midnight

200 California Ave.
Treasure Island, SF
FREE=09=09=09=09

Brian Salazar

Paul Gordon
Michelle Sanz

Moi

Although Sunday Sessions is, strategically, placed at the tail end of
the weekend, The Endup's newest monthly, THE RHYTHM ROOM, is the
most evident way to top off that action packed weekend and a
memorable and enlightening way to start off the next work week.
Showcasing the bay area's grooviest and most reputable upcoming
local djs, THE RHYTHM ROOM promises to offer a night of the
catchiest, most innovative and intellectually produced DEEP, FUNKY,
SOULFUL, AFRO house music out there triggering an emotion deep in
our rhythmic souls making all of us dance like we never have before.
Tie your shoes, bring a sweat towel, and call a friend or 3 and join
the rest of us! There's friends to be made and music to be
introduced. MEET UP @ THE ENDUP for THE RHYTHM ROOM, a Brian Salazar
production.

From: Layla Lewis <layla6942@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-1823074707-1236806694=:11865"

Subject: [sfraves] BSP- Pufuchu Says: The Weekend Starts Here

--0-1823074707-1236806694=:11865
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

yes, it really does. not only does the weekend start now (well, in a
couple hours) there are sooooo many things to choose from that, well,
this might get a little long. so skipping the usual witty intro and
getting right down to it!




Wednesday Mar 11th


when i said now i meant it! happy hour with the false profit
family! and celebrating the victory of brainchief! pizza, cheap beer
($3 red stripe) and good beats! 

EQUITY
Il Pirate (16th @ Utah)
6pm-9pm free

DJ Daps
Ganucheau


and if you thought i was kidding, i meant it when i said the weekend starts now! check this out!


Glimmer of Dope and Connected Grooves present:

DEEPCHILD
Nikola Baytala
Mr. Projectile
Mozaic
Jared F

103 Harriet (alley by Folsom @ 6th)
10pm - 3:30 am
$10 / $5 b4 11pm with RSVP @
www.going.com/deepchild

there are a few other events tonight but if you're on facebook you already have a gazillion invites for them!




Thursday Mar 12th


you'd think that just maybe since it seems everyone is doin an
event on wednesday this week that thursday would be a no-brainer, but
NO! i haven't seen MILK yet and they're showing it for free at the SF
Green Party HQ at 7pm so i might start my night there. otherwise, yup,
out of the gazillion things to choose from i recommend these two:


TRANSPORTED
bus stop gallery 
135 Dore unit C. (btw. 9th and 10th @ Folsom)
8pm-12am
$21 (www.brownpapertickets.com/event/58841)

Kid Kameleon
Space Invader
Little John

i
know the ticket price seems steep for a thursday but the bus is the
bomb! and to make up for the cost it's BYOB!!!! so jump on the bus and
check out the sites while rockin out with the transported crew! and
afterwards, walk over to shine and continue the night!



Shameless presents TECHNOCOLOR
Shine (Mission @ 9th)
10pm-2am
FREE!

DJ Icon
Dex Stakker
Jen Woolfe
MC Shahid Buttar


yup.
it's only thursday and already i feel exhausted! and i thought about
telling everyone to take it easy the rest of the weekend and go catch a
movie or something, but i don't think that's possible really. 




Friday Mar 13th


i might skip town to go to big mike's birthday but if i stay you might find me at one of these events....


YNOT?
NIMBY 8410 Amelia St. Oakland
$10

BAM
Mozaic
Alixr
Indigo
Boychaos
Raydeus
Sparkinzi 

and the Ambient Mafia in the side room!

come
help get Tuffy on the road! 2 rooms of music and the line-up is sick
AND an area for fire-dancers? if you were disappointd at the lack of
flames at carl cox come check this out!

and because party hoppin is always fun, here's another east bay event!

ORISHAS
5306 Foothill Blvd. Oakland
9pm-6am
$15

in honor of the spirits...

Stereographic LIVE
Parus
Dr. Spook
Nicolo
God Intoxicated
Chloro Djinn
Satir
Arwin

i
know it's psytrance so it's probably a surprise to see it on my list
but i do enjoy it quite a bit sometimes, and i figure since so often we
wind up hearing the same music from the same djs it might be time to
try something new!

exhausted yet? i am. with that in mind, i'm
gonna wrap it up. go see a movie, have a dinner party, maybe even get a
good nights sleep. when was the last time that happened on the weekend?
maybe someone will be inspired by a sunny sunday! see you all on the
dancefloor!

peace love and beats- pufuchu


      
--0-1823074707-1236806694=:11865--

*Friday, March 13th*

10 PM - 4 AM
21+

Rock It Science presents:

*DJ Fame (NYC - Dubsided, Potty Mouth Music)*

DJ Fame is an instrumental artist redefining house music for the 21st
century, with releases on Switch & Jesse Rose=92s Dubsided imprint, Chicago=
=92s
Potty Mouth Music and many more. His energetic performances showcase seriou=
s
technical ability combined with intense cuts, crazy loops, and other
turntablist tricks to bring a new style and sound to the dance floor. This
illuminating stage presence and a rightfully-earned air of confidence sets
him apart from so many peers and makes him truly one of the hottest young
talents on the dance scene. Don=92t miss his debut performance at Temple!

*Shrine:*

DJ Fame (Dubsided, Potty Mouth)
Eric Sharp (Rock It Science)
Goldsweat DJs (Loco vs Belly Up)
*
Destiny Lounge:*

DJ Fortune (Milwaukee - For U Events)
Homero Espinosa (Yerba Buena Discos)
*
Catacombs:
*
Tone (Temple)
Von (djvon.com)

*Free before midnight with RSVP to eric@rockitsciencesf.com*

Temple Nightclub
540 Howard Street @ 2nd, San Francisco

Friday (TOMORROW) March 13th...

Tuffy is going on a Great Adventure and to make sure she can get on the road we are throwing her a benefit at NIMBY.

www.nimbyspace.org
 

2 music rooms and an outdoor fire spinning / dancing / hooping area. 
BAM (Evil Breaks) 
MOZAIC (Raindance) 
ALIXR (Pulse/FnF) 
INDIGO (FnF)
RAYDEUS (Pronoia/Raydeus.com) 
SPARKINZI (Sparkdoo.dz)

and
THE AMBIENT MAFIA will be running the downtempo room/hookah lounge.

CUMULUS (WoM) 
CUBIK Y ORIGAMI (Dinner Party) 
WE ARE NOT PANDAS (WanP) 
SQUELCHY (Vocoid)
OLDE NASTY (Butterzone)
THE CAPTAIN (Chill Syndicate) 
and special guest, BOYCHAOS (Underworld) 

Visuals provided by Heroic Robot and SICK sound by Know Audio and Def Audio. 

Tuffy is no music slouch so be prepared to dance your pants off. Everyone and your mother is coming, so YNOT you?

----------------------------------------------------
 www.redstickman.com

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: AFTERGLOW this Sunday w/ Solar, Lance DeSardi, & Sassmouth. 
	FREE!

--000e0cd213debc550004651da4bf
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Afterglow was conceived as a chance to wind down after a long weekend by
listening to some chill music and having a few drinks with friends. The idea
is to allow some of SF's most talented and multi-faceted dance music DJ's an
opportunity to dig deeper into their collections and play music they
wouldn't be able to in a club setting. Anything's game, from ambient and
electronica, to dub techno, idm, atmospheric drum n bass downtempo, future
jazz, deep house and beyond.

flyer:
http://i67.photobucket.com/albums/h320/bird415/AG03r.png

website:
http://www.afterglowsf.com

venue:
http://www.nickies.com

friend us @:
http://www.myspace.com/afterglowsf


___________________________________


This month's special guests:

SOLAR   (sunset, bang the box)

SASSMOUTH   (n.f.b.c : chicago/london)

and

LANCE DESARDI   (landshark, bang the box)

__________________________________


Come on, admit it!  Aren't you curious to hear what they're going to play?

Hope to see you out. Full bar, yummy food til 1am, and as always, it's FREE!

Let's get mellow. :)

--000e0cd213debc550004651da4bf--

From: George Cochrane <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: mike guglielmini <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] new to the board


...In before the curmudgeons!

SF has a pretty vibrant club scene with a lot of "Underground" music finding its way into bonafide club nights.  There are tons of exceptionally good DJs, producers and performers in the area.  The UG rave scene is not blowing up like it was back in its 90's and early 00's heyday, but there are still cool parties here and there if you're searching for something outside the club zone.  The day parties that happen in summertime outdoors are like nothing else and a big highlight.

The quality of life is ridiculously good (if you get a good job and can afford it, though I think prices in Miami are close if not on par already).  Food, fun, weather (if you're ok with a little cold and rain occasionally) and culture are great. 

-GC

Employment picture sucks here right now (I just lost my gig) but the underground scene is great.  Seriously, we're all jaded and forget how lucky we are to have what we have in SF.  While we don't have anything like WMC, the Lovefest in September is pretty amazing.  

I guess that's not very curmudgeonly... 

Welcome to the list.

What sort of music are you playing these days?  Hope you like fog...

Best,

Peter



----- Original Message ----
From: mike guglielmini <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Tuesday, March 17, 2009 10:44:18 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] new to the board

not bad. i was around back when the scenes were good around 96 or so. making money shouldnt be a problem, i get a va benefits check every month and i spin whenever i can land decent gigs. underground scene is exactly what im looking for as there is absolutely none here. im not too big on clubs tho i do go to them a lot just because thats pretty much all thats left. anythings got to be better than miami.

--- On Tue, 3/17/09, George Cochrane <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:


From: George Cochrane <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] new to the board
To: "mike guglielmini" <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Tuesday, March 17, 2009, 1:38 PM



....In before the curmudgeons!

SF has a pretty vibrant club scene with a lot of "Underground" music finding its way into bonafide club nights.  There are tons of exceptionally good DJs, producers and performers in the area.  The UG rave scene is not blowing up like it was back in its 90's and early 00's heyday, but there are still cool parties here and there if you're searching for something outside the club zone.  The day parties that happen in summertime outdoors are like nothing else and a big highlight.

The quality of life is ridiculously good (if you get a good job and can afford it, though I think prices in Miami are close if not on par already).  Food, fun, weather (if you're ok with a little cold and rain occasionally) and culture are great. 

-GC

Subject: [sfraves] Stap[e: Primer Happy Hour - Thursday, March 19 @ WISH

--000e0cd151fe7c2da90465556edf
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Stap[e: Primer Happy Hour

Wish

Thurs, March 19



With special guest, Eli Bingham
And Resident DJs:

Qzen
Javaight
Fil Latorre

Stap[e Primer Happy Hour returns with special guest Eli Bingham (Nightlight
Music).

While he was getting a college education in the late '90s Bay Area, he
discovered the local rave scene - specifically the local techno scene, at
events thrown by Friends & Family, Mad, Gateway Systems, and Static. Eli's
officially retired from  the music scene these days, but always happy to
make a cameo appearance.

Recent Mix:  http://discodoreradio.blogspot.com/



Primer focuses on providing an outlet for DJs to bring their true crate gems
that they may not bust out on the dancefloor. Stuff for the mind and for the
soul.  Expect to hear deep eclectic music...always.

--000e0cd151fe7c2da90465556edf--

re in sf? from what im reading it looks ok.

EB 5 - The E.B. Dream Team

Saturday, April 4th, 2009
Mezzanine (444 Jessie St.) 
9pm-4am

Cost if on the 700+ person list: (signup box @ EvilBreaks.com)
The 1st 100 arrivals - FREE!
The next 100 arrivals - $5
All other listees half-price until the list closes @ 11pm - $10
Door Cost: $20 


In keeping with past E.B. Anniversary shows, we want to thank everyone for supporting us in the past couple of years, and although this lineup is so insane we can't do it completely free for hundreds of people like we've been doing, we hope that you like what we can offer. Sign up is now open down below......

This show has been 5 years in the making, & we have decided to go HUGE!!! A ridiculous lineup, a ridiculous venue, a ridiculous price......You know how we do, & with this show, we're going to put everything we've ever done to shame. Get ready.

(Diverted Traffic/TCR/Sokolov Sounds/I-Breaks)

w/Simple Greene (Strategik) opening the main room.....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] new to the board

Parallel party, not a relocation.  SFLoveFest not a big as the Love
Parade, but our scene is dynamic and friendly.  There are a ton of
intimate, smaller parties, rather than big, iconic ones, though there
are a handful of well known crews in the area with reputations for
their parties.

You'll get people who think it's the best, who complain it's nothing
like berlin|somewhereineurope, and everything in between.  Really, the
biggest thing I can say is that it's what you make it.  If you expect
to see or find thousands or even hundreds of like-minded fans around
you every weekend, you will likely be disappointed, but in terms of
filling the generally smaller venues we've got as we can get them,
hey, it's an intense time.

-R.

Semper, motehrfalucking Fi.

Devil Dog.

Ooooh rah.

Technically, because I got out of my signed, Contractual Obligations to
Preserve, Protect and Defend The US Constitution of the United States of
America on 21 Sep 1990, the VA considers me a GW I Combat Vet, only because
I was in USMC uniform on 3 Aug 1990 the day Saddam's tanks went a rollin'
into Kuwait, on the very fucking DAY my contract went under 100 days and I
became a 2 digit midget.

doh.

Anyways, right now, I'm out of the USA, I'm living in Munich, Germany,
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DjN6g50avv64 right now, with plans to move =
to
Berlin with my GF, Maja, http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DoAnPgpDERJw on 1
September, 2009, so I can realize my plans to
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DcYj1nkwMp4k  (if Apollo was still subbed h=
ere
he would *totally* get that Hitler Invades Poland reference), so, like,
y'know, dude, you and I should talk further.

And if you are so inclined, this is an open invite to come out and visit if
you ever hop the pond again and make your way east.

Marine Corps Ravers Unite, and shit.

Welcome to SFRaves Party, http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3D2kJSq5bo8uI Teuf=
el
Hund.

Oh, and if you're over the age of 25, feel free to look up Raver Geriatric
here on Hyperreal, and introduce yourself to Mary W., who is also subbed to
SoCal Raves, in case you fall below the minimum age requirement of RG.

I'm sure she'd like you.

A lot.

Peisces,

Nyc

their parties.

You'll get people who=0A think it's the best, who complain it's nothing
like berlin|somewhereineurope, and everything in between.=A0 Really, the
biggest thing I can say is that it's what you make it.=A0 If you expect
to see or find thousands or even hundreds of like-minded fans around
you every weekend, you will likely be disappointed, but in terms of
filling the generally smaller venues we've got as we can get them,
hey, it's an intense time.

-R.

became a 2 digit midget.

--- On Wed, 3/18/09, Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net> wrote:


From: Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] new to the board
To: "mike guglielmini" <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Wednesday, March 18, 2009, 4:36 PM


Parallel party, not a relocation.=A0 SFLoveFest not a big as the Love
Parade, but our scene is dynamic and friendly.=A0 There are a ton of
intimate, smaller parties, rather than big, iconic ones, though there
are a handful of well known crews in the area with reputations for
their parties.

You'll get people who think it's the best, who complain it's nothing
like berlin|somewhereineurope, and everything in between.=A0 Really, the
biggest thing I can say is that it's what you make it.=A0 If you expect
to see or find thousands or even hundreds of like-minded fans around
you every weekend, you will likely be disappointed, but in terms of
filling the generally smaller venues we've got as we can get them,
hey, it's an intense time.

-R.

--- On Tue, 3/17/09, George Cochrane <newstylesound@yahoo.com> wrote:


From: George Cochrane <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] new to the board
To: "mike guglielmini" <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Tuesday, March 17, 2009, 1:38 PM



......In before the curmudgeons!




SF has a pretty vibrant club scene with a lot of "Underground" music findin=
g its way into bonafide club nights.=A0 There are tons of exceptionally goo=
d DJs, producers and performers in the area.=A0 The UG rave scene is not bl=
owing up like it was back in its 90's and early 00's heyday, but there are =
still cool parties here and there if you're searching for something outside=
 the club zone.=A0 The day parties that happen in summertime outdoors are l=
ike nothing else and a big highlight.

The quality of life is ridiculously good (if you get a good job and can aff=
ord it, though I think prices in Miami are close if not on par already).=A0=
 Food, fun, weather (if you're ok with a little cold and rain occasionally)=
 and culture are great.

-GC

new blood! nice!

so mike, i recently hooked up a residency at the Ruby Skye monthy Torq which 
happens to be going down tonight. Marcus Schossow is in town & he sounds 
like someone who'd might be up your musical alley. I've been to south beach 
many a time and know how bad and unwelcome most high "brow clubs" can be - 
but i've found this particular night to be different in that it's a bit more 
party friendly and the crowd don't seem to have their egos stuck up there 
ass.  Those who know me can verify that this Ruby night must be different 
than most if they made ME a resident. LOL

ALSO... i just came upon 2 extra guestspots, which i'd like to offer to you 
and a friend (but plz accept only if your sure you can make it in their door 
by 11pm guestspot cut off time)
if you're down, just hit me back by 3pm today with the word (and the name of 
your friend if you go & want to bring one).

here's a link with some info on it:
http://www.rubyskye.com

welcome to town & happy livin'

`d

new blood! nice!

so mike, i recently hooked up a residency at the Ruby Skye monthy Torq which 
happens to be going down tonight. Marcus Schossow is in town & he sounds 
like someone who'd might be up your musical alley. I've been to south beach 
many a time and know how bad and unwelcome most high "brow clubs" can be - 
but i've found this particular night to be different in that it's a bit more 
party friendly and the crowd don't seem to have their egos stuck up there 
ass. Those who know me can verify that this Ruby night must be different 
than most if they made ME a resident. LOL

ALSO... i just came upon 2 extra guestspots, which i'd like to offer to you 
and a friend (but plz accept only if your sure you can make it in their door 
by 11pm guestspot cut off time)
if you're down, just hit me back by 3pm today with the word (and the name of 
your friend if you go & want to bring one).

here's a link with some info on it:
http://www.rubyskye.com

welcome to town & happy livin'

`d

As many of you may know, our good friend and much loved community =20
member Dave Olazabal passed suddenly on January 13th.  Also known as =20
Big Rave Dave and Acme Dave, David was well-known for throwing =20
excellent parties like Ascension and Herbonium among others.

There will be a memorial for him on Ocean Beach tomorrow night and a =20
picnic on Saturday.  Details  below (this list doesn't accept =20
attachments so the flier is now text only without maps).  Please join =20=

us in honoring Dave's memory and sending him some collective love.  =20
Forward this information to others who might be interested.

Much love,

Apollo


Please join the Olazabal family for a Memorial to David Parlier Olazabal

Friday evening, March 20th
at Ocean Beach, in San Francisco; (at the Great Highway and Fulton St.)
937 Great Highway, San Francisco, CA 94122

David Parlier Olazabal

November 23, 1979 =96 January 13, 2009

Join us on the beach; between stairwells 15-20 (depending upon =20
availability)
Sunset is at about 7:20 pm, and we will be lighting the bonfire around =20=

8:00 pm
Please feel free to bring a letter or message for Dave to throw into =20
the bonfire.


Directions To The Bonfire
 =46rom Oakland
1. Take I-880 N to the Bay Bridge
2. Merge onto I-80 W
3. Take exit 1B
to merge onto US-101 N
4. Take exit 434B
      toward Fell St/Octavia Blvd
5. Merge onto Octavia St
6. Turn left at Fell St
7. Turn right at Shrader St
8. Turn left at Fulton St
9. Turn left at The Great Hwy
10. Stairwell 15 is at the parking lot entrance



Those unable to attend the bonfire are welcome to attend a
potluck memorial for Dave on Saturday, March 21, 2009 at
Fort Miley in San Francisco; the picnic will begin at noon.

Directions to the Picnic
 =46rom Oakland follow steps 1-6 of the bonfire directions
7. =46rom Fell St. turn right at Divisadero St.
8. Turn left at Geary Blvd.
9. Continue on Point Lobos Ave.
10. Turn right at El Camino del Mar St.
11. It is a moderate uphill walk from the parking lot to the
Fort Miley picnic area at.



apollo@speakeasy.org

MySpace:  http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo

Tribenet:   http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
  =3D
Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things that =20=

you didn't do than by the ones you did do. So throw off the bowlines. =20=

Sail away from the safe harbor. Catch the trade winds in your sails. =20
Explore. Dream. Discover.  Mark Twain - American Author

=3D
"Come to the edge."
"We can't. We're afraid."
"Come to the edge."
"We can't. We will fall!"
"Come to the edge."
  And they came.
  And he pushed them.
  And they flew.

   Guillaume Apollinaire,   1880-1918



--Apple-Mail-10--633960353--

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Saturday, 3/21/09 | 10 PM - Late | 21 +

Rock It Science Presents: Dirty Secrets - Eric Sharp's Bday Edition

Dirty Secrets busts out again in a fresh warehouse space perfect for an
evening of shenanigans. One of SF's busiest fun-makers, Rock It Science
founder Eric Sharp invites all of you to join him in celebrating another
year of existence on this lovely planet and has organized a great lineup of
DJ friends to throw down in celebration. Come early and stay late as you
won't want to miss a beat!

DJs for the night:

Jeno (Back 2 Back)
Andrew Phelan (Prismatic)
Eric Sharp (Rock It Science, Flavor Group)
Michael Anthony (Supperclub)
Bo (Deep Blue)
Bass Cadet (Rock It Science)
White Girl Lust (Solid Bump)

Info Line courtesy of Prismatic (call for location the night of):

888 482 9281

Hope to see you there!

--000e0cd110b2080a14046585f83f--

Subject: [sfraves] Oh yeah... my Tuesday night Reveiw: Shelter

OK.. so I got some time to kill while I wait for m Yaya to get here.. =20
so yeah.. like Tuesday night was fuckin' ILL!!  I had sooooooo much =20
fun!!!  Like the journey there was kidna confuzing... took the buses =20
then the bart & got to the Embarcaderro BART stop.... like I swear =20
man, i always have a hella bad sense of direction when i get off that =20
station, & when I like finally got above ground, I swear I coldn't =20
find like the bus stop for 15 mintues 'cause I didn't know which =20
stairway I went up and what intersection I ended up on... hello2day!

So I eventually got to Lower Haight &  then went to the pizza place =20
next to UGSF & oh my goodness man... had the best fuckin' pizza... =20
it's called the White Pizza & ooh man... mondo fucki'n yum!!  Then =20
after my mini dinner-ish meal... I got an strawberry shortcake ice =20
cream bar & a bag of chocolates @ walgreens cross the street... yeah =20
man.. I wanted to visit Mister Origami, but man, I totally forgot your =20
cell number Homie :(  I mean...since I was right there, ya know!

But yeah.. the night started @ Shelter & opening DJ did this like hip =20
hop into jungle set, the next DJ, Rayze, was all up in the Liquid =20
Jungle, the tag set w/ Noah & Jett after that, they totally just =20
well... I heard soem Jump Up, but not enough for me to get my groovy =20
on the dance floor... ooh shit... then this like well.. I dunno if =20
he's a newbie DJ to the scene & this was his 1st gig or what, but this =20
dude, Big Sound I think his name was.. fuuuuuckin' a man... homeboy =20
totally busted out all the old school junlge & man... i was dancin' my =20
ass off, well, as much as possible anyway... but yeah... so yum!!!

Then the headlining DJ, A-Sides, totally like ummm.. fuck man... HELLO =20
2DAY.. his set was sick... I mean... he fuckin' all over all the sub =20
genres, played everything & made the dance floor hella hyphy... I =20
mean... fuckin' A man... he dropped alota genres I don't normally like =20
get my groovy on to, but the way he mixed them in, like his track =20
selection was fuckin' sick & I coudln't not dance!!

It was hella Dope 'cause like MAx, MC DUH, like totally MCed the way =20
he duh-z & made us all on the dance floor more hyphy!  LoL.. Hello =20
2day.. so like I told this joke to 1 of the pormoters, 'cause like =20
alota the decorations that night like there were these paper balls =20
hangin' from the ceiling by green ribons... & I just made a joke to =20
like Noah, the promoter dude, "Hey man, there be hella balls hangin' =20
from the ceiling, it's like a fuckin' tea bag party man"... then he =20
started hella laughing & told max & Max yelled that comment onthe mic =20
& eeeeeeeveryone started laughing, it was hella funny man!!! :D

So yeah... vibe was sooo good & even if the energy was kinda yucky at =20
one point no wait, a few points during the night, everyohne was Lovin' =20
it!!!  It's really nice to see Shelter have it's own following after =20
Phuturo left... but yeah... it was good!!

Something lame that happened was well.. ok.. so these 2 like ok.. I'm =20
gonna call them Candy Raver Junglist 1 (CRJ1) & Candy Raver Junglist 2 =20
(CRJ2).. so anywaze, well.. long story short, CRJ1 slept w/ CRJ2's =20
"ex"-gf when they were still like together & stuff... as soon as CRJ2 =20
saw CRJ1, they argue & CRJ2 pops CJR1 in the eye, causing himself to =20
get 86ed... so CJR1 goes outside & they have this mondo arguement on =20
the sidewalk.. so like me & the other oldskoolers are like hangin back =20
by the door watching & kinda laughing 'cause well.. the whole fuckin' =20
premise of them fuckin' fighting was fuckin' lamesauce to 100th degree =20
man... CRJ1 & 2 even had their other friends get involved & they wre =20
yelling at each other too...Hello 2day... b ut yeah.. since CRJ2 =20
didn't have a ride home, he was jsut there on the sidewalk like just =20
waiting for the night to end so his ride could take him home... =20
eventually CRJ1 (I mean.... this like tiny scrawny skinny 5'3-4 lil =20
Latino dude) he got totally wasted & 86ed from the owner of UGSF.. it =20
pretty entertaining actually to watch all that!! :)

But yeah... so it was a totally good night & the Jungle... HELLO =20
2DAY!!!!  The journey home now.. that was pretty interesting... I =20
walked to Powell bart from Lower Haight & like well.. I stopped of @ =20
the donut joint on Van Ness & Market & got a strawberry quick bottle & =20
a mondo jumungo cinnimon bun.. yum... ok... some guy, like homeless =20
druggie strung out on crack dude, offered me sex for some change =20
'cause he said he hasn't eaten in  days... & i was like =20
Heeeeeeeeeeeelll Naaaaaaaaaw & I said "Dude, if you laid off the =20
fuckin' crack pipe & actually ate, then you wouldn't be hungry!"  Then =20
when i was alsmot @ the station, some other homeless crack head asked =20
me for change so he can go home to SanJose 'cause he's been stuck in =20
the City for the past month... yeah... whatev... well... by 6:15AM I =20
was home... it was a good night!!! :)

Oh... Yaya says Hello SF Rers!  She misses y'all!!  Yaya aka Delia aka =20
KittyCat

Peace=3D->
Just Me=3D->
Osby {8O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] dress codes for parties in sf


Its easy to get a California ID if you already have the source or breeder documents such as a birth certificate etc.  If you don't have those and you've lost your MD ID, you might have issues.  But that's not just going to be a California issue; you'll have this problem everywhere.

FWIW until recently I worked for a company in the business of detecting false identity documents.  So I am familiar with CA and other state regulations in this area.

Best,

Peter

Yeah it is pretty easy.  Get a copy of your medical records and set up an
appointment with a pot doc (medicann is pretty good).  They'll make
a judgment call if anything in your medical history warrants
being prescribed marijuana for (they have pretty loose standards).
Medicann's website: http://www.medicannusa.com/

Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks


Well, a lot of people have been switching recently I think.  The primary issues seem to be portability and cost.  The laptop interfaces have gotten better of course as well.  

I'm just a hobbyist, but with the economy I'm not investing in anything new right now so still vinyl for me.  

SF has been a vinyl mecca for a long time, but I think that time may be fading...see for example the recent demise of Open Mind and the rework at Tweekin' records here.  The days when we had half a dozen dance oriented vinyl stores are gone forever.

Peter

First, when did DJs ever have musical skills?
Ok seriously tho, if you are still doing the beatmatching I don't see why it
matters if you do it on plain vinyl, cd decks, or a digital vinyl solution.
 The only time I call foul is if you use software to do the beatmatching for
you.  Also, beatmatching with the bpm detect function on new gear is
borderline ;)

However, there is one case where I think having software align all the beats
for you is okay, and that is if you are doing a reasonably complex live PA
with something like Ableton.  If you have more then three tracks playing at
once, I personally think its acceptable to have software help.

Just my $0.02

--000e0cd487725736e304658f6b23
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

The early house and techno pioneers embraced technology to create
"electronic" music.  Knowing your history is the essential part in
understanding where you're at.  But are we content with that?  Should DJs
also stop playing music made with software, and not analog hardware?  While
the 1200s are classic, and there's nothing quite like spinning on vinyl, I'd
compare my ableton live setup and mid controller to an F22 fighter jet.
It's capable of mind boggling things, especially when you compare it to an
above average DJ on a pair of technics, which is more like a propellor
driven WWII plane.

It's kind of funny, cuz all the kids who are new to the scene, are
completely mesmerized by ableton live and curious about how it works.  But a
lot of the old heads, grunt then mumble something under their breadth when
they see someone on it.  These are the same people 10, 15 years ago who
stood in front of the DJ, mezmerized by the continuous grooves that churned
out of 2 or 3 turntables.

--- On Fri, 3/20/09, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:


From: dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] dress codes for parties in sf
To: "mike guglielmini" <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Friday, March 20, 2009, 12:08 PM



Its easy to get a California ID if you already have the source or breeder documents such as a birth certificate etc.  If you don't have those and you've lost your MD ID, you might have issues.  But that's not just going to be a California issue; you'll have this problem everywhere.

FWIW until recently I worked for a company in the business of detecting false identity documents.  So I am familiar with CA and other state regulations in this area.

Best,

Peter

Date: Fri, 20 Mar 2009 10:29:10 -0700 (PDT)
From: George Cochrane <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: mike guglielmini <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks


Vinyl (and even CDJs) are a little like manual transmission on a car.  For some folks, it affords a feeling of increased control, but really, most folks that say they would "only drive a stick" are saying so because of macho chest-puffing.  

Laptop DJing is a little like a modern automatic transmission.  When needed, it makes a task that requires little to no skill (beatmatching) automatic.  It can take a little bit of control away from the driver, but it frees them up to focus on other things.  Modern automatic transmissions afford the user plenty of control, and many have "manual-like" modes.

Now imagine that these automatic cars were 4 times lighter and more efficient than manuals, could hold 400 times as much gas, and folded up into a suitcase, and you'll have an idea of what the appeal is.

When I DJ these days, I use DJ software like Torq, which gives me the option to beatmatch myself or to auto-beatmatch (but that usually takes some finesse, it's not perfect).  The nice thing is, I can 2x4 with a dj who's playing vinyl or cds, beatmatch with them, and once I get going, flip into auto-mode and focus on really fucking with the sound for a little while if I want.  Most DJ software lets you control the audio with actual turntables if you want, but I forego that, mainly because I love to be able to set up my small gear, plug it in right as the previous DJ is playing (without screwing up the setup) and go go go!  The whole setup fits in a small backpack I can easily carry on my bike.

However, I will assert that somebody's GOT to have a good controller to make laptop djing legit.  Even I get pissed when I'm watching somebody sit there and throw tracks into itunes or plop them into an Ableton timeline with little-to-no interaction.

-George

--- On Fri, 3/20/09, Matt Stone <matthew.d.stone@gmail.com> wrote:


From: Matt Stone <matthew.d.stone@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks
To: "mike guglielmini" <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>

First, when did DJs ever have musical skills?


Ok seriously tho, if you are still doing the beatmatching I don't see why it matters if you do it on plain vinyl, cd decks, or a digital vinyl solution.  The only time I call foul is if you use software to do the beatmatching for you.  Also, beatmatching with the bpm detect function on new gear is borderline ;)


However, there is one case where I think having software align all the beats for you is okay, and that is if you are doing a reasonably complex live PA with something like Ableton.  If you have more then three tracks playing at once, I personally think its acceptable to have software help.


Just my $0.02

Okay, so here's the thing with programs that automatically beatmatch like
ableton.  If you're only mixing from channel 1 to channel to, at the end of
every song, I completely understand your argument.  However, that's not how
ableton is meant to be utilized.  There are quite a few DJs who use ableton
in this manner, and I've heard of one legend on the playa who often mixes in
this manner.

Ableton is better suited for piecing loops of musics, into new songs.  It's
also great for remixing songs live, or doing live editing.  I can layer a
photek drum n bass loop at 135 BPM, add in some keys from a DJ Shadow song,
add a vocal sample, percussion from here and there, a wobbly acid line, and
I've got a new fucking song on the spot!  Can you do this on turntables,
well, actually you can.  Since turntablism has gone underground, there's a
lot of cats, especially in SF who are perfecting this artform.  Have you
seen the vestax turntable that has buttons to adjust pitch speed,
essentially turning the turntable into a real instrument.  You have groups
like Gunkhole and 4oneFunk who have pieces of a live band like a drummer,
then lay down all the other elements: bassline, solos, melodies, leads, etc,
with different members of the group using their turntables to add to the
song, it's rather insane.

However, unless you have 4 or 5 highly skilled turntablist to create a new
song, ableton let's you do it all on your own.

Check out gunkhole creating live music on turntables here:

http://video.google.com/videosearch?client=firefox-a&rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&channel=s&hl=en&q=funkhole&um=1&ie=UTF-8&sa=N&tab=wv#q=gunkhole&hl=en&emb=0

DJ Teeko doing a solo on the scratch 1 vestax turntable:
http://video.google.com/videosearch?client=firefox-a&rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&channel=s&hl=en&q=funkhole&um=1&ie=UTF-8&sa=N&tab=wv#q=dj+teeko+solo&hl=en&emb=0

Ableton for Mac = yes.

Remixing in Ableton = yes (although it's way more fun to stop hacking on 
other people's shit and just write your own music in Ableton, or if you 
feel like saving some money and don't mind learning some key commands, get 
started today with ReNoise *it's free and quite badass*)

As far as a controller goes, you absolutely have to use a: 
http://saturn5.com/andy/images/caltrain/phatboy-oakie.JPG (not available 
in stores, but I can make you one, I can even put a fake Oakie signature 
with "With Love Frum IBITHAARH" in silver pen on the back so it's just 
like mine)

As for the whole topic of DJing:

DJing can suck my fucking balls, long live DJing.

Hello world, my name is Andy.  You might know me as a mild mannered 
sysadmin, who likes to write long posts but at night I change.  I change 
into things.  Among the things I turn into are dj, guitarist, producer, 
editor, guitarist, sound system tuner, dancer, shittalker, beer guzzler, 
and freak of nature.

Oh wait, no I don't.  I don't change at all, I'm all those things.  They 
are not identities, they are traits or abilities or interests.

The whole concept of the DJ as a figure worthy of respect boggles my mind.  
I've done my time as one (something like 13 years now).  I've played back 
to back with people like Christian Smith, DJ Rush, and John Selway.  I've 
raged 5000 people at once and also had that sinking feeling when the only 
person on the dancefloor does that 'look busy and walk away' thing while 
my favorite track is playing.  I've helped throw some pretty darn spiffy 
underground events and clubs, put out a couple records, been a long 
standing and vocal personality on this list, and probably been called a 
self-righteous douche more than your dad (no, not the guy your mom was 
married to, your *real* dad, the pool guy).

The funny thing about this is that nobody seems to know who I am these 
days.  The music that I came in on, techno, is still played.  But nobody 
seems to remember me.  I still make music, I still love it, but I just 
don't get asked to much.

So what's my point other than talking about myself?  I don't need one.  
Just kidding.  My point is that you should do what you love, for the love 
of it, and not count on something outside yourself to define yourself.  
Your success and satisfaction should come from within, and be of yourself.  

About a year ago, I went to a club that was GOING OFF INSANELY to some kid 
who wasn't even born in 1983 playing Human League off an iPod, 
trainwrecking merrily from track to track.  And it made me want to 
bitchslap him, really hard, repeatedly.  I thought of my ability, and his 
lack thereof.  My skill, my talent, my records, my gear, my energy.

My ass.  I was jealous.  Just plain petty.

DJing is just playing music these days.  Some people know how to 
beatmatch, and that's cool.  Some people have some rare tunes that will 
break your brain, and that's cool.  Some people will never 'dj' out 
anywhere, but they meticulously set up playlists for when they're cooking, 
gardening, watching porn, whatever.  Some people just like jamming out 
to whatever is new that week and don't think much of what's good or 
bad, they just ride this timeline of stuff that comes out.  And that's 
cool.

Don't dream of being a succesful DJ.  If you like the music you pick and 
how you bring it in, you already are.  The point I'm making is do what you 
love with music, and people might get it.  With format, sure I have 
preferences, but I gotta hand it to the guy with the iPod playing Human 
League, he was killing it.  For all my knowledge of music, deep bag of 
vinyl tricks, zen philosophies and their applications to performance and 
strange experiences... that night I was just the grumpy looking bastard 
with the crossed arms.

andyw

p.s.  And you can have your laptops, and your cds, I miss the beauty of 
vinyl... where else can you get beautiful artwork like this:
http://saturn5.com/andy/images/mj_vs_et.jpg

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From sfraves-return-150468-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Mar 20 19:17:28 2009

From: littleetoile@aol.com

X-Mailer: AOL Webmail 41921-STANDARD
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org

X-Spam-Flag: NO
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks

----------MB_8CB77A7A582AEE4_B38_23B8_MBLK-M09.sysops.aol.com
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"


 What Andy said before I got a chance to. Yeah.

Seriously though- and maybe this is because I'm not a DJ so I don't have any personal investment (or, admittedly, a trained ear/musical knowledge/etc.), but- why the fuck should it matter?

A DJ is there to rock the crowd. Period. If software is assisting with that, who cares? Does it mean we should enjoy ourselves less? Does it mean it detracts from the experience? The only thing it detracts from is DJ worship (uuuuwww he can beatmatch!) and I don't think that matters. Again, maybe this is just because I'm not knowledgeable enough on the ins and outs of turntabling, but seems to me that the people who are pissed about this software being used are really just butthurt that they're not in the cool club anymore. The resistance to the software is the resistance to ego loss. "But, but, he's cheating! I CAN DO WHAT HE DOES WITHOUT THAT SOFTWARE!" That's great, and not to say that your abilities and talent shouldn't be respected, but guess what? It's not about you. It's about whether you get people shaking it on the dancefloor, software-assisted or not.

If anything, I think it could lead the way for some serious breakthroughs because it lends itself to increased creativity and working outside the box. With the beatmatching hurdle eliminated, for example, people have more freedom to tweek shit around and focus on other aspects. It also encourages DJs to try new things and push the envelope to set themselves apart from every other DJ Tom, Dick or Harry who is relying on the same software to do what previously had to be learned. Does that make sense? 

If suddenly everyone can do what was already done, it means DJing has to be reinvented to up the ante. The previous lowest common denominator of DJ skillz (yes, with a "z") has now been eliminated from the equation so the bar for success has to be set higher. That could lead to some amazing shit and I'm all for it. If you're a real lover of dance music, if you're a true musician and in it to make amazing music and rock the crowd, then you would be, too. You would be embracing this opportunity to revitalize the art and create anew, thrilled by the avenues this open us, the seemingly infinite possibilities of where this could take dance music and DJing. Not to say that vinyl and turntabling shouldn't still be appreciated and respected, but the people who are pissed about this change are really just freaked out about being sussed out and left behind because they know they don't possess the musicianship to meet these new challenges.


Still not a DJ,
Alida



 

-----Original Message-----
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
To: mike guglielmini <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Fri, 20 Mar 2009 11:13 am
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks











On Fri, 20 Mar 2009, mike guglielmini wrote:
-&e->now that i can agree with. as long as your still doing the 
-&e->beatmatching yourself. ableton is a little different tho from mp3 
-&e->mixing because with ableton you can do live remixes and shit from 
-&e->what im told. havent actually looked into it yet but plan too soon. 
-&e->can you get ableton on mac? cuz i hate pc.. especially for media 
-&e->applications.

Ableton for Mac = yes.

Remixing in Ableton = yes (although it's way more fun to stop hacking on 
other people's shit and just write your own music in Ableton, or if you 
feel like saving some money and don't mind learning some key commands, get 
started today with ReNoise *it's free and quite badass*)

As far as a controller goes, you absolutely have to use a: 
http://saturn5.com/andy/images/caltrain/phatboy-oakie.JPG (not available 
in stores, but I can make you one, I can even put a fake Oakie signature 
with "With Love Frum IBITHAARH" in silver pen on the back so it's just 
like mine)

As for the whole topic of DJing:

DJing can suck my fucking balls, long live DJing.

Hello world, my name is Andy.  You might know me as a mild mannered 
sysadmin, who likes to write long posts but at night I change.  I change 
into things.  Among the things I turn into are dj, guitarist, producer, 
editor, guitarist, sound system tuner, dancer, shittalker, beer guzzler, 
and freak of nature.

Oh wait, no I don't.  I don't change at all, I'm all those things.  They 
are not identities, they are traits or abilities or interests.

The whole concept of the DJ as a figure worthy of respect boggles my mind.  
I've done my time as one (something like 13 years now).  I've played back 
to back with people like Christian Smith, DJ Rush, and John Selway.  I've 
raged 5000 people at once and also had that sinking feeling when the only 
person on the dancefloor does that 'look busy and walk away' thing while 
my favorite track is playing.  I've helped throw some pretty darn spiffy 
underground events and clubs, put out a couple records, been a long 
standing and vocal personality on this list, and probably been called a 
self-righteous douche more than your dad (no, not the guy your mom was 
married to, your *real* dad, the pool guy).

The funny thing about this is that nobody seems to know who I am these 
days.  The music that I came in on, techno, is still played.  But nobody 
seems to remember me.  I still make music, I still love it, but I just 
don't get asked to much.

So what's my point other than talking about myself?  I don't need one.  
Just kidding.  My point is that you should do what you love, for the love 
of it, and not count on something outside yourself to define yourself.  
Your success and satisfaction should come from within, and be of yourself.  

About a year ago, I went to a club that was GOING OFF INSANELY to some kid 
who wasn't even born in 1983 playing Human League off an iPod, 
trainwrecking merrily from track to track.  And it made me want to 
bitchslap him, really hard, repeatedly.  I thought of my ability, and his 
lack thereof.  My skill, my talent, my records, my gear, my energy.

My ass.  I was jealous.  Just plain petty.

DJing is just playing music these days.  Some people know how to 
beatmatch, and that's cool.  Some people have some rare tunes that will 
break your brain, and that's cool.  Some people will never 'dj' out 
anywhere, but they meticulously set up playlists for when they're cooking, 
gardening, watching porn, whatever.  Some people just like jamming out 
to whatever is new that week and don't think much of what's good or 
bad, they just ride this timeline of stuff that comes out.  And that's 
cool.

Don't dream of being a succesful DJ.  If you like the music you pick and 
how you bring it in, you already are.  The point I'm making is do what you 
love with music, and people might get it.  With format, sure I have 
preferences, but I gotta hand it to the guy with the iPod playing Human 
League, he was killing it.  For all my knowledge of music, deep bag of 
vinyl tricks, zen philosophies and their applications to performance and 
strange experiences... that night I was just the grumpy looking bastard 
with the crossed arms.

andyw

p.s.  And you can have your laptops, and your cds, I miss the beauty of 
vinyl... where else can you get beautiful artwork like this:
http://saturn5.com/andy/images/mj_vs_et.jpg

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org




 


----------MB_8CB77A7A582AEE4_B38_23B8_MBLK-M09.sysops.aol.com--

Part of my enjoyment of a DJ is knowing what kind of technical skills they
have.  Sorry, just it.  I understand if other people consume a DJ's output
only through the filter of "what does it sound like", but many of us also
listen for transitions, where the dj cuts in, etc.  I don't think that is
wrong, just different.


>
> If anything, I think it could lead the way for some serious breakthroughs
> because it lends itself to increased creativity and working outside the box.
> With the beatmatching hurdle eliminated, for example, people have more
> freedom to tweek shit around and focus on other aspects. It also encourages

> the musicianship to meet these new challenges.
>

Or it could lead to a new era of laziness, where DJs spend more time dancing
around, looking cool, and having software blow through their preselected
playlist.  I personally don't think eliminating the skill of beatmatching is
a positive, but hey, you are all free to disagree :)  At some point you have
to ask yourself "how am I different then a bar mitzvah DJ".

On Fri, Mar 20, 2009 at 12:39 PM, Matt Stone <matthew.d.stone@gmail.com>wrote:

>
>
> On Fri, Mar 20, 2009 at 12:17 PM, <littleetoile@aol.com> wrote:
>
>>
>>  What Andy said before I got a chance to. Yeah.
>>
>> Seriously though- and maybe this is because I'm not a DJ so I don't have
>> any personal investment (or, admittedly, a trained ear/musical
>> knowledge/etc.), but- why the fuck should it matter?
>>
>> A DJ is there to rock the crowd. Period. If software is assisting with
>> that, who cares? Does it mean we should enjoy ourselves less? Does it mean
>> it detracts from the experience? The only thing it detracts from is DJ
>> worship (uuuuwww he can beatmatch!) and I don't think that matters. Again,
>> maybe this is just because I'm not knowledgeable enough on the ins and outs
>> of turntabling, but seems to me that the people who are pissed about this
>> software being used are really just butthurt that they're not in the cool
>> club anymore. The resistance to the software is the resistance to ego loss.
>> "But, but, he's cheating! I CAN DO WHAT HE DOES WITHOUT THAT SOFTWARE!"
>> That's great, and not to say that your abilities and talent shouldn't be
>> respected, but guess what? It's not about you. It's about whether you get
>> people shaking it on the dancefloor, software-assisted or not.
>>
>
> Part of my enjoyment of a DJ is knowing what kind of technical skills they
> have.  Sorry, just it.  I understand if other people consume a DJ's output
> only through the filter of "what does it sound like", but many of us also
> listen for transitions, where the dj cuts in, etc.  I don't think that is
> wrong, just different.
>
>
>>
>> If anything, I think it could lead the way for some serious breakthroughs
>> because it lends itself to increased creativity and working outside the box.
>> With the beatmatching hurdle eliminated, for example, people have more
>> freedom to tweek shit around and focus on other aspects. It also encourages
>> DJs to try new things and push the envelope to set themselves apart from
>> every other DJ Tom, Dick or Harry who is relying on the same software to do
>> what previously had to be learned. Does that make sense?
>>
>> If suddenly everyone can do what was already done, it means DJing has to
>> be reinvented to up the ante. The previous lowest common denominator of DJ
>> skillz (yes, with a "z") has now been eliminated from the equation so the
>> bar for success has to be set higher. That could lead to some amazing shit
>> and I'm all for it. If you're a real lover of dance music, if you're a true
>> musician and in it to make amazing music and rock the crowd, then you would
>> be, too. You would be embracing this opportunity to revitalize the art and
>> create anew, thrilled by the avenues this open us, the seemingly infinite
>> possibilities of where this could take dance music and DJing. Not to say
>> that vinyl and turntabling shouldn't still be appreciated and respected, but
>> the people who are pissed about this change are really just freaked out
>> about being sussed out and left behind because they know they don't possess
>> the musicianship to meet these new challenges.
>>
>
> Or it could lead to a new era of laziness, where DJs spend more time
> dancing around, looking cool, and having software blow through their
> preselected playlist.  I personally don't think eliminating the skill of
> beatmatching is a positive, but hey, you are all free to disagree :)  At
> some point you have to ask yourself "how am I different then a bar mitzvah
> DJ".
>

PS, "I play better tracks" isn't a good answer :)

>> Ableton for Mac = yes.
>>
>> Remixing in Ableton = yes (although it's way more fun to stop hacking on
>> other people's shit and just write your own music in Ableton, or if you
>> feel like saving some money and don't mind learning some key commands, get
>> started today with ReNoise *it's free and quite badass*)
>>
>> As far as a controller goes, you absolutely have to use a:
>> http://saturn5.com/andy/images/caltrain/phatboy-oakie.JPG (not available
>> in stores, but I can make you one, I can even put a fake Oakie signature
>> with "With Love Frum IBITHAARH" in silver pen on the back so it's just
>> like mine)
>>
>> As for the whole topic of DJing:
>>
>> DJing can suck my fucking balls, long live DJing.
>>
>> Hello world, my name is Andy.  You might know me as a mild mannered
>> sysadmin, who likes to write long posts but at night I change.  I change
>> into things.  Among the things I turn into are dj, guitarist, producer,
>> editor, guitarist, sound system tuner, dancer, shittalker, beer guzzler,
>> and freak of nature.
>>
>> Oh wait, no I don't.  I don't change at all, I'm all those things.  They
>> are not identities, they are traits or abilities or interests.
>>
>> The whole concept of the DJ as a figure worthy of respect boggles my mind.
>> I've done my time as one (something like 13 years now).  I've played back
>> to back with people like Christian Smith, DJ Rush, and John Selway.  I've
>> raged 5000 people at once and also had that sinking feeling when the only
>> person on the dancefloor does that 'look busy and walk away' thing while
>> my favorite track is playing.  I've helped throw some pretty darn spiffy
>> underground events and clubs, put out a couple records, been a long
>> standing and vocal personality on this list, and probably been called a
>> self-righteous douche more than your dad (no, not the guy your mom was
>> married to, your *real* dad, the pool guy).
>>
>> The funny thing about this is that nobody seems to know who I am these
>> days.  The music that I came in on, techno, is still played.  But nobody
>> seems to remember me.  I still make music, I still love it, but I just
>> don't get asked to much.
>>
>> So what's my point other than talking about myself?  I don't need one.
>> Just kidding.  My point is that you should do what you love, for the love
>> of it, and not count on something outside yourself to define yourself.
>> Your success and satisfaction should come from within, and be of yourself.
>>
>> About a year ago, I went to a club that was GOING OFF INSANELY to some kid
>> who wasn't even born in 1983 playing Human League off an iPod,
>> trainwrecking merrily from track to track.  And it made me want to
>> bitchslap him, really hard, repeatedly.  I thought of my ability, and his
>> lack thereof.  My skill, my talent, my records, my gear, my energy.
>>
>> My ass.  I was jealous.  Just plain petty.
>>
>> DJing is just playing music these days.  Some people know how to
>> beatmatch, and that's cool.  Some people have some rare tunes that will
>> break your brain, and that's cool.  Some people will never 'dj' out
>> anywhere, but they meticulously set up playlists for when they're cooking,
>> gardening, watching porn, whatever.  Some people just like jamming out
>> to whatever is new that week and don't think much of what's good or
>> bad, they just ride this timeline of stuff that comes out.  And that's
>> cool.
>>
>> Don't dream of being a succesful DJ.  If you like the music you pick and
>> how you bring it in, you already are.  The point I'm making is do what you
>> love with music, and people might get it.  With format, sure I have
>> preferences, but I gotta hand it to the guy with the iPod playing Human
>> League, he was killing it.  For all my knowledge of music, deep bag of
>> vinyl tricks, zen philosophies and their applications to performance and
>> strange experiences... that night I was just the grumpy looking bastard
>> with the crossed arms.

-----Original Message-----
From: Matt Stone <matthew.d.stone@gmail.com>
To: littleetoile@aol.com
Cc: andy@saturn5.com; djdarkchyld@yahoo.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Fri, 20 Mar 2009 12:39 pm
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks





"Part of my enjoyment of a DJ is knowing what kind of technical skills they
have.  Sorry, just it.  I understand if other people consume a DJ's output
only through the filter of "what does it sound like", but many of us also
listen for transitions, where the dj cuts in, etc.  I don't think that is
wrong, just different."

Right, which is why I prefaced my statement with pointing out that my opinion may just be
because I'm not a DJ/don't have a trained ear. But this is sort of a
moot point, given what I said below about it opening up new avenues for
creativity. This would still provide that experience you crave, I think.


"Or it could lead to a new era of laziness, where DJs spend more time dancing
around, looking cool, and having software blow through their preselected
playlist.  I personally don't think eliminating the skill of beatmatching is
a positive, but hey, you are all free to disagree :)  At some point you have
to ask yourself 'how am I different then a bar mitzvah DJ'."


I don't think this will be the case. Yes, it will certainly make this
possibility more accessible, but that type of turntabling has always
existed (e.g. nightclubs, discotheques, etc.) and nothing is changing
that. The DJs to whom that appeals to will continue to play that way,
and the dancers to whom that appeals to will continue to frequent those
events. Just because laziness is accessible, doesn't mean people will
settle for it. If that were the case, we'd all just be sitting in a
room together listening to itunes (or a CD player, or a record player,
or a radio, in days past). 

But that's not the case, is it? People have
*always* demanded a more spontaneous, fluid, interactive creative
experience, just as people have always been impassioned to provide
that. And as always, the people who are not willing to meet this new
era of possibility will fall back, and those that are will rise up. It's as simple as that.


STILL not a DJ,
Alida

> On Fri, 20 Mar 2009, mike guglielmini wrote:
> -&e->now that i can agree with. as long as your still doing the
> -&e->beatmatching yourself. ableton is a little different tho from mp3
> -&e->mixing because with ableton you can do live remixes and shit from
> -&e->what im told. havent actually looked into it yet but plan too soon.
> -&e->can you get ableton on mac? cuz i hate pc.. especially for media
> -&e->applications.
>
> Ableton for Mac = yes.
>
> Remixing in Ableton = yes (although it's way more fun to stop hacking on
> other people's shit and just write your own music in Ableton, or if you
> feel like saving some money and don't mind learning some key commands, get
> started today with ReNoise *it's free and quite badass*)
>
> As far as a controller goes, you absolutely have to use a:
> http://saturn5.com/andy/images/caltrain/phatboy-oakie.JPG (not available
> in stores, but I can make you one, I can even put a fake Oakie signature
> with "With Love Frum IBITHAARH" in silver pen on the back so it's just
> like mine)
>
> As for the whole topic of DJing:
>
> DJing can suck my fucking balls, long live DJing.
>
> Hello world, my name is Andy.  You might know me as a mild mannered
> sysadmin, who likes to write long posts but at night I change.  I change
> into things.  Among the things I turn into are dj, guitarist, producer,
> editor, guitarist, sound system tuner, dancer, shittalker, beer guzzler,
> and freak of nature.
>
> Oh wait, no I don't.  I don't change at all, I'm all those things.  They
> are not identities, they are traits or abilities or interests.
>
> The whole concept of the DJ as a figure worthy of respect boggles my mind.
> I've done my time as one (something like 13 years now).  I've played back
> to back with people like Christian Smith, DJ Rush, and John Selway.  I've
> raged 5000 people at once and also had that sinking feeling when the only
> person on the dancefloor does that 'look busy and walk away' thing while
> my favorite track is playing.  I've helped throw some pretty darn spiffy
> underground events and clubs, put out a couple records, been a long
> standing and vocal personality on this list, and probably been called a
> self-righteous douche more than your dad (no, not the guy your mom was
> married to, your *real* dad, the pool guy).
>
> The funny thing about this is that nobody seems to know who I am these
> days.  The music that I came in on, techno, is still played.  But nobody
> seems to remember me.  I still make music, I still love it, but I just
> don't get asked to much.
>
> So what's my point other than talking about myself?  I don't need one.
> Just kidding.  My point is that you should do what you love, for the love
> of it, and not count on something outside yourself to define yourself.
> Your success and satisfaction should come from within, and be of yourself.
>
> About a year ago, I went to a club that was GOING OFF INSANELY to some kid
> who wasn't even born in 1983 playing Human League off an iPod,
> trainwrecking merrily from track to track.  And it made me want to
> bitchslap him, really hard, repeatedly.  I thought of my ability, and his
> lack thereof.  My skill, my talent, my records, my gear, my energy.
>
> My ass.  I was jealous.  Just plain petty.
>
> DJing is just playing music these days.  Some people know how to
> beatmatch, and that's cool.  Some people have some rare tunes that will
> break your brain, and that's cool.  Some people will never 'dj' out
> anywhere, but they meticulously set up playlists for when they're cooking,
> gardening, watching porn, whatever.  Some people just like jamming out
> to whatever is new that week and don't think much of what's good or
> bad, they just ride this timeline of stuff that comes out.  And that's
> cool.
>
> Don't dream of being a succesful DJ.  If you like the music you pick and
> how you bring it in, you already are.  The point I'm making is do what you
> love with music, and people might get it.  With format, sure I have
> preferences, but I gotta hand it to the guy with the iPod playing Human
> League, he was killing it.  For all my knowledge of music, deep bag of
> vinyl tricks, zen philosophies and their applications to performance and
> strange experiences... that night I was just the grumpy looking bastard
> with the crossed arms.
>
> andyw
>
> p.s.  And you can have your laptops, and your cds, I miss the beauty of
> vinyl... where else can you get beautiful artwork like this:
> http://saturn5.com/andy/images/mj_vs_et.jpg
