--00163646c7b69f3519046592835d
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

actually, "I play better tracks" is as valid an answer as it is possible to
give for that question.  the biggest factor in a set being good or sucking
is.....Track Selection!  and who would have guessed people care more about
hearing great songs than they do about hearing great transitions?  that's
why the iPod dj can blow up a place even if he trainwrecks every mix: he's
playing the right song for the moment and that is what counts the most.
that's by no means to say selection is the only factor, but you can be just
plain decent at mixing, nothing terribly special, and people will love your
sets if you're a great track selector and can keep a groove going.

if you think ableton etc. will lead us to a new era of lazy, bad dj'ing, i'd
like to ask if you think we'd be better off if those same people still
became dj's but used vinyl.  they'd still probably be terrible and lazy
about the things that really matter, and they'd have beatmatching to praise
themself for if they learn how to do it.  i don't think we'd be better off
at all.

i started dj'ing towards the end of the vinyl era, but decks were still the
thing to get so i learned how to beatmatch and cue a record.  took practice
but (and let me emphasize this) it's the kind of skill that almost anyone
could learn if they practice seriously.  that's all beatmatching is, a skill
anyone can learn if they take the time.  the lowest common denominator of
the dj world.  when i first went to college i had no room for decks, a
mixer, and vinyl, so i made friends with someone who had CDJ's and kept
right on going.  i've used ableton off and on depending on if i had access
to CDJs at the time, cause it's that or just quitting for a while.  i guess
what i'm saying is, technology changes.  use what's useful to you, and
barring that use what you can get.  there's no reason to hold one piece of
technology in esteem over others just because it's older.

lastly, i am in complete agreement with everything Andy and Alida said
better than i could.

> >> that, who cares? Does it mean we should enjoy ourselves less? Does it
> mean

> >> worship (uuuuwww he can beatmatch!) and I don't think that matters.
> Again,
> >> maybe this is just because I'm not knowledgeable enough on the ins and
> outs
> >> of turntabling, but seems to me that the people who are pissed about
> this
> >> software being used are really just butthurt that they're not in the
> cool
> >> club anymore. The resistance to the software is the resistance to ego
> loss.
> >> "But, but, he's cheating! I CAN DO WHAT HE DOES WITHOUT THAT SOFTWARE!"
> >> That's great, and not to say that your abilities and talent shouldn't be
> >> respected, but guess what? It's not about you. It's about whether you
> get
> >> people shaking it on the dancefloor, software-assisted or not.
> >>
> >
> > Part of my enjoyment of a DJ is knowing what kind of technical skills
> they
> > have.  Sorry, just it.  I understand if other people consume a DJ's
> output
> > only through the filter of "what does it sound like", but many of us also
> > listen for transitions, where the dj cuts in, etc.  I don't think that is
> > wrong, just different.
> >
> >
> >>
> >> If anything, I think it could lead the way for some serious
> breakthroughs
> >> because it lends itself to increased creativity and working outside the
> box.
> >> With the beatmatching hurdle eliminated, for example, people have more
> >> freedom to tweek shit around and focus on other aspects. It also
> encourages
> >> DJs to try new things and push the envelope to set themselves apart from
> >> every other DJ Tom, Dick or Harry who is relying on the same software to
> do
> >> what previously had to be learned. Does that make sense?
> >>
> >> If suddenly everyone can do what was already done, it means DJing has to
> >> be reinvented to up the ante. The previous lowest common denominator of
> DJ
> >> skillz (yes, with a "z") has now been eliminated from the equation so
> the
> >> bar for success has to be set higher. That could lead to some amazing
> shit
> >> and I'm all for it. If you're a real lover of dance music, if you're a
> true
> >> musician and in it to make amazing music and rock the crowd, then you
> would
> >> be, too. You would be embracing this opportunity to revitalize the art
> and
> >> create anew, thrilled by the avenues this open us, the seemingly
> infinite
> >> possibilities of where this could take dance music and DJing. Not to say
> >> that vinyl and turntabling shouldn't still be appreciated and respected,
> but
> >> the people who are pissed about this change are really just freaked out
> >> about being sussed out and left behind because they know they don't
> possess
> >> the musicianship to meet these new challenges.
> >>
> >
> > Or it could lead to a new era of laziness, where DJs spend more time
> > dancing around, looking cool, and having software blow through their
> > preselected playlist.  I personally don't think eliminating the skill of
> > beatmatching is a positive, but hey, you are all free to disagree :)  At

On Fri, Mar 20, 2009 at 1:10 PM, Matthew Johnson
<prayformojo524@gmail.com>wrote:

> actually, "I play better tracks" is as valid an answer as it is possible to
> give for that question.  the biggest factor in a set being good or sucking
> is.....Track Selection!


Am I not allowed to disagree with this point? What if track selection is
only half of the picture for my ears?  Am I some elitist?


>   and who would have guessed people care more about hearing great songs
> than they do about hearing great transitions?  that's why the iPod dj can
> blow up a place even if he trainwrecks every mix: he's playing the right
> song for the moment and that is what counts the most.  that's by no means to
> say selection is the only factor, but you can be just plain decent at
> mixing, nothing terribly special, and people will love your sets if you're a
> great track selector and can keep a groove going.
>
> if you think ableton etc. will lead us to a new era of lazy, bad dj'ing,
> i'd like to ask if you think we'd be better off if those same people still
> became dj's but used vinyl.  they'd still probably be terrible and lazy
> about the things that really matter, and they'd have beatmatching to praise
> themself for if they learn how to do it.  i don't think we'd be better off
> at all.
>
> i started dj'ing towards the end of the vinyl era, but decks were still the
> thing to get so i learned how to beatmatch and cue a record.  took practice
> but (and let me emphasize this) it's the kind of skill that almost anyone
> could learn if they practice seriously.  that's all beatmatching is, a skill
> anyone can learn if they take the time.  the lowest common denominator of
> the dj world.  when i first went to college i had no room for decks, a
> mixer, and vinyl, so i made friends with someone who had CDJ's and kept
> right on going.  i've used ableton off and on depending on if i had access
> to CDJs at the time, cause it's that or just quitting for a while.  i guess
> what i'm saying is, technology changes.  use what's useful to you, and
> barring that use what you can get.  there's no reason to hold one piece of
> technology in esteem over others just because it's older.
>
> lastly, i am in complete agreement with everything Andy and Alida said
> better than i could.
>
>

>> >> bar for success has to be set higher. That could lead to some amazing

>> only
>> >> person on the dancefloor does that 'look busy and walk away' thing
>> while
>> >> my favorite track is playing.  I've helped throw some pretty darn
>> spiffy
>> >> underground events and clubs, put out a couple records, been a long

>> nobody
>> >> seems to remember me.  I still make music, I still love it, but I just
>> >> don't get asked to much.

>> >> So what's my point other than talking about myself?  I don't need one.
>> >> Just kidding.  My point is that you should do what you love, for the
>> love
>> >> of it, and not count on something outside yourself to define yourself.

>> >> About a year ago, I went to a club that was GOING OFF INSANELY to some

>> >> who wasn't even born in 1983 playing Human League off an iPod,

>> >> bitchslap him, really hard, repeatedly.  I thought of my ability, and

>> >> lack thereof.  My skill, my talent, my records, my gear, my energy.

>> >> gardening, watching porn, whatever.  Some people just like jamming out

>> >> cool.

>> >> how you bring it in, you already are.  The point I'm making is do what

>> >> strange experiences... that night I was just the grumpy looking bastard

Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks


This is the thing, grasshopper:


----- Original Message ----
From: Matt Stone <matthew.d.stone@gmail.com>

Part of my enjoyment of a DJ is knowing what kind of technical skills they
have.  Sorry, just it.  I understand if other people consume a DJ's output
only through the filter of "what does it sound like", but many of us also
listen for transitions, where the dj cuts in, etc.  I don't think that is
wrong, just different.

---

Beatmatching is a rote skill, as basic as riding a bike.  It's a neat trick, but it's not art.  Track selection, transitions, reacting to the crowd, energy management, creative sound processing- these are arts, and quite technical..  And all of them happen in today's laptop DJing, whether the DJ chooses to beatmatch themselves or not.  In fact, laptop djs have the capability to have more tracks, MUCH better processing options, more control, more creative tools, etc.  

---
Or it could lead to a new era of laziness, where DJs spend more time dancing
around, looking cool, and having software blow through their preselected
playlist.  I personally don't think eliminating the skill of beatmatching is
a positive, but hey, you are all free to disagree :)  At some point you have
to ask yourself "how am I different then a bar mitzvah DJ".
---


But what do you call that 3-5 minute chunk in the middle of most dj tracks where the dj has little to do but drop the bass out here and there and try to look like they're doing something?  That doesn't change in laptop djing, only when i hit that chunk, I can choose to totally fuck shit up, mix in loops from 3 other tracks, or whatever.  It's like giving performer a box full of new toys.  All one can do in vinyl is match up another track and start mixing them together.  The best djs can really get shit going that way, but most of them are on Serato these days anyway.

I agree- people trying to act like a performer while a preselected playlist plays are turds- but those people aren't djs or performers, and they don't represent the state of the art of what people are doing with laptops.  My dj gigs have as much adrenaline and danger as ever- I just have a lot more say in the way shit sounds.

-G

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

On Fri, 20 Mar 2009, Matt Stone wrote:
-&e->On Fri, Mar 20, 2009 at 12:17 PM, <littleetoile@aol.com> wrote:
-&e->
-&e->>
-&e->>  What Andy said before I got a chance to. Yeah.
-&e->>
-&e->> Seriously though- and maybe this is because I'm not a DJ so I don't have
-&e->> any personal investment (or, admittedly, a trained ear/musical
-&e->> knowledge/etc.), but- why the fuck should it matter?

You don't have to be a trapeze artist to enjoy the circus, ya know?

-&e->> A DJ is there to rock the crowd. Period. If software is assisting with
-&e->> that, who cares? Does it mean we should enjoy ourselves less? Does it mean
-&e->> it detracts from the experience? The only thing it detracts from is DJ
-&e->> worship (uuuuwww he can beatmatch!) and I don't think that matters. Again,
-&e->> maybe this is just because I'm not knowledgeable enough on the ins and outs
-&e->> of turntabling, but seems to me that the people who are pissed about this
-&e->> software being used are really just butthurt that they're not in the cool
-&e->> club anymore. The resistance to the software is the resistance to ego loss.
-&e->> "But, but, he's cheating! I CAN DO WHAT HE DOES WITHOUT THAT SOFTWARE!"
-&e->> That's great, and not to say that your abilities and talent shouldn't be
-&e->> respected, but guess what? It's not about you. It's about whether you get
-&e->> people shaking it on the dancefloor, software-assisted or not.

Eh, it chaps my ass a bit too, but I'm coming to realize it's because I 
practiced *a lot* for years and years and years and it seems cheap.

-&e->Part of my enjoyment of a DJ is knowing what kind of technical skills they
-&e->have.  Sorry, just it.  I understand if other people consume a DJ's output
-&e->only through the filter of "what does it sound like", but many of us also
-&e->listen for transitions, where the dj cuts in, etc.  I don't think that is
-&e->wrong, just different.

I love the craft of DJing off vinyl, don't get me wrong.

-&e->> If anything, I think it could lead the way for some serious breakthroughs
-&e->> because it lends itself to increased creativity and working outside the box.
-&e->> With the beatmatching hurdle eliminated, for example, people have more
-&e->> freedom to tweek shit around and focus on other aspects. It also encourages
-&e->> DJs to try new things and push the envelope to set themselves apart from
-&e->> every other DJ Tom, Dick or Harry who is relying on the same software to do
-&e->> what previously had to be learned. Does that make sense?

In theory yes, in practice no.  It creates a new path of least resistance.  
I've seen DJ after DJ that basically have their set all laid out in 
software before they play.  You could shoot them dead and the only change 
you'd hear is less annoying filter/cut action.  I want all the new 
technology to make music better, but it's just not.  I'm really starting 
to love these old sets that have been popping up, just two decks and a 
Rane MP-24 (a mixer that didn't have gains or per channel eq, but just 
sounded fucking great).  Music wasn't so compressed, you had to know your 
records better before per channel EQs became popular, etc.

http://www.thegathering-sf.com/music.html <- old school gear + records = !

-&e->> If suddenly everyone can do what was already done, it means DJing has to be
-&e->> reinvented to up the ante. The previous lowest common denominator of DJ
-&e->> skillz (yes, with a "z") has now been eliminated from the equation so the
-&e->> bar for success has to be set higher. That could lead to some amazing shit
-&e->> and I'm all for it. If you're a real lover of dance music, if you're a true
-&e->> musician and in it to make amazing music and rock the crowd, then you would
-&e->> be, too. You would be embracing this opportunity to revitalize the art and
-&e->> create anew, thrilled by the avenues this open us, the seemingly infinite
-&e->> possibilities of where this could take dance music and DJing. Not to say
-&e->> that vinyl and turntabling shouldn't still be appreciated and respected, but
-&e->> the people who are pissed about this change are really just freaked out
-&e->> about being sussed out and left behind because they know they don't possess
-&e->> the musicianship to meet these new challenges.

The world is changing, and what I've noticed is that the sun is setting on 
DJing in general.  The technology already exists to beatmatch most of the 
stuff out there from computer control.  Soon, your aunt will be able to 
play a beatmatched funk + disco set while doing the dishes out of media 
player or itunes, just pick the genre, tempo and feel.  Most of the best 
artists I met in DJ-land are moving towards bands, live collaboration, 
production and other art forms.  We have to ask ourselves if we're just 
seeing the tide turn back after putting too much stock in an idea.

I personally find that I like my music with less changes, more hypnotic, 
than crowds seem to these days.  I can't stand electro-house, the rave 
revival shit that's been coming out... too many cheesy cliche'd changes, 
it's ADD as all hell, it never seems to really settle into a _groove_.  
But as ravE gave way to Club, the chemistry of the partygoers has 
changed... and hell, I can play my old mixes or go out and catch some 
dubstep, house or maybe hit up a techno weekly if I want to hear what I 
want to hear.

-&e->Or it could lead to a new era of laziness, where DJs spend more time dancing
-&e->around, looking cool, and having software blow through their preselected
-&e->playlist.  I personally don't think eliminating the skill of beatmatching is
-&e->a positive, but hey, you are all free to disagree :)  At some point you have
-&e->to ask yourself "how am I different then a bar mitzvah DJ".

Ask yourself that *now*.  You're not.  In fact, I'd be willing to say it's 
*harder* in some ways to take requests, not offend the old people while 
not boring the young people and be the wedding/prom kinda DJ than it is to 
have my name on a flyer and have the expectation to play what the fuck I 
want.  It's fun to watch a room full of peoples hands go up in the air and 
eyes roll back when you're fucking killing it in a build mix... not so 
much watching a bunch of akward people do the Electric Slide or slow 
dance to Crazy for You *one*more*time*.

At the "heyday" of the time I was playing parties, I was working my 
goddamn ass off.  I didn't plan sets ahead of time but knew my records 
cold, I read the crowd, I usually packed two boxes (named Fat Man and 
Little Boy) if I was planning on playing more than an hour.  I scratched, 
I eq'd, I hot mixed, I beat juggled and banged doubles, I three decked, 
tag teamed, 2x4'd, etc.  I bought records like crazy, when I walked into 
Open Mind or Solid Grooves, there would usually be a small pile of records 
put aside for me, cause these people knew what I liked.

And I was making about a third as much per booking, and seeing less 
bookings, as a pair of goons who played 8-12 minute long records end to 
end, often repeating the same set night after night.  The records almost 
all had the same rhythm, no swing, only came out on a few labels, and 
featured *obvious* "mix here" points where the bassline fell out making 
their lives easy.  They looked so bored mixing, except when the tracks 
would build, when their hands would come up and they'd do their fake 
cheerleader shit.  Their popularity drove me batshit, I hated them.

And 25 years from now, they'll be the ones who are remembered.

Vinyl is not a guarantee of skill.  DJing is not a meritocracy, it just is 
what it is.  If someone is picking out prerecorded music and playing it, 
they're a DJ.  Everything else is a matter of opinion and taste.

andyw

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

this phenomenon is rooted in a couple hard to take realities.... first and =
foremost, most of the music these days is not being released on vinyl. it's=
 almost all entirely digital download. even though using something like fin=
al scratch or tractor preserves some semblance of what most people think wh=
en they see the word "dj" why go the extra step?=20

also, at least here in sf, (or perhaps in my families) so many people incor=
porate their own music, whether finished tracks or layering components that=
 ableton live does make more sense.

there will always be shitty djs and producers. because we're on the leading=
 edge of new technologies which theoretically make djing and producing "eas=
ier" and the lower cost of digital technology definitely makes it more fina=
ncially accessible to every frikkin idiot that wants to be a star there is =
perhaps a flood of subpar production and sets these days but in the end qua=
lity will win out. i hope.=20

and yes. there is still vinyl. you gotta warn a promoter, otherwise there w=
on't be needles on
the tables, but vinyl is still loved. and because of the rarity when things=
 get released on vinyl it's usually really good.=20

the thing that drives me insane? low quality mp3s. if you're gonna spin dig=
ital, go for the wav or flak version of the tracks. it makes a difference o=
n the bigger sound systems. please, i'm beggin you all out there!!! no low =
quality mp3s on the big bins!!!!

peace love and beats- layla

References: <136758.47894.qm@web111107.mail.gq1.yahoo.com> <Pine.LNX.4.62.0903200956450.12304@atari> <8CB77A7A4E7B68C-B38-119C@MBLK-M09.sysops.aol.com> <b6d812240903201239nf8e90d7x5c459b6e281a732f@mail.gmail.com>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.930.3)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks

On Mar 20, 2009, at 12:39 PM, Matt Stone wrote:

> Part of my enjoyment of a DJ is knowing what kind of technical  
> skills they
> have.  Sorry, just it.  I understand if other people consume a DJ's  
> output
> only through the filter of "what does it sound like", but many of us  
> also
> listen for transitions, where the dj cuts in, etc.  I don't think  
> that is
> wrong, just different.

You go girl- but respecting a DJ for "technical skills" is IMO the  
same as respecting someone because of their Guitar Hero abilities.
Sure, they've got that little talent down pat, but I'm not going to  
rip my top off and offer myself to them just because I see it in action.
DJs have only 1.5 functions for me- 1) play good music .5) that I  
haven't heard before

Sure, people like Andy and George may describe what they do as DJs and  
call it creative, but I think they don't see the forest for the trees-  
and I think that what they do ventures entirely in to the realm of  
production and they should call it such, using decks or CDJs or  
whatever as just one of the tools.

I make music myself, and historically I mentally modeled the  
difference between "producer" and "DJ" as "Am I playing someone else's  
music or am I playing my own?"- but that devolves in to "Am I using  
inbuilt ROM sounds/samples or my own?"- and then if you want to get  
all Zen it becomes "I didn't create that Crow that just made a noise  
that I recorded, God did- am I still legit?"

Ultimately such thought is meaningless and stupid and will drive you  
mad, so ultimately "the DJ" should be thought of just as I said-  
someone who can play good music and might play something you haven't  
heard before.

-N7

Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks


Interestingly in the radio business the conventional wisdom is that people only want to listen to songs they've heard before, because most people will switch stations if a song they don't know comes on.  

So the best rated radio DJs often never play anything new at all...

Funny I think.

Peter



----- Original Message ----
From: Nathan Seven <n7@nathanseven.com>
To: Matt Stone <matthew.d.stone@gmail.com>
Cc: littleetoile@aol.com; andy@saturn5.com; djdarkchyld@yahoo.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Friday, March 20, 2009 7:55:25 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks

On Mar 20, 2009, at 12:39 PM, Matt Stone wrote:

> Part of my enjoyment of a DJ is knowing what kind of technical skills they
> have.  Sorry, just it.  I understand if other people consume a DJ's output
> only through the filter of "what does it sound like", but many of us also
> listen for transitions, where the dj cuts in, etc.  I don't think that is
> wrong, just different.

You go girl- but respecting a DJ for "technical skills" is IMO the same as respecting someone because of their Guitar Hero abilities.
Sure, they've got that little talent down pat, but I'm not going to rip my top off and offer myself to them just because I see it in action.
DJs have only 1.5 functions for me- 1) play good music .5) that I haven't heard before

Sure, people like Andy and George may describe what they do as DJs and call it creative, but I think they don't see the forest for the trees- and I think that what they do ventures entirely in to the realm of production and they should call it such, using decks or CDJs or whatever as just one of the tools.

I make music myself, and historically I mentally modeled the difference between "producer" and "DJ" as "Am I playing someone else's music or am I playing my own?"- but that devolves in to "Am I using inbuilt ROM sounds/samples or my own?"- and then if you want to get all Zen it becomes "I didn't create that Crow that just made a noise that I recorded, God did- am I still legit?"

Ultimately such thought is meaningless and stupid and will drive you mad, so ultimately "the DJ" should be thought of just as I said- someone who can play good music and might play something you haven't heard before.

-N7

Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks

i'm not so sure.. i think it would be better to rep the local people in 
your area that are making tracks if your are going to be the DJ 
ambassador thing. so many people making music now its better to get 
localized and dig up shit that nobody has anywhere else but home. that 
way if you as a dj put together music from your town somebody in sydney 
or tokyo is going to shit bricks and try to understand why the SF sound 
is so hot. then they in turn will make us shit bricks with their stuff. 
and much terracotta will be rectally emanated world wide.

    in a sense the computer is still pushing out  the boundaries if you 
can think outside the box a bit. the computer, musically, is sort of 
shooting holes in conventional thought every day. there are so many 
tangents and communications going on world wide that things are 
advancing at an exponential rate. this is a great time for music. get on 
board or get left behind. i feel it is the people that can think a few 
steps ahead and the people who have their fingers on the pulse of what 
could happen that could really make the difference in the overall 
direction of music.

but then again there is that luddite fear.. getting on the bandwagon. 
i've staved off from buying a laptop for music for so long because 
things have been building up and phasing out so quickly i felt that as 
soon as i had enough money to buy the gear it would have been outdated. 
but i don't think i can afford to wait any longer.

sean.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I'm with you Mike on the wording.

It is a serious stretch to call what is happening now with computers and 
the DJ, real dj'ing.  From either an etymological point of view, from a 
physical point of view or from a practical point of view.  I know many 
new jacks love this technology, and the argument can be made that it 
does not replace skill, to some degree.

But there is skill in being in a dark club, digging through heavy crate 
of records, trying to read a label, slapping it down on a deck, getting 
the pitch just right, and coming in at the right point.  That physical 
activity , I think, is what the crowd unconsciously grooves to, because 
the act of anticipation is actually seen as you witness a DJ take a 
platter off and put one one.  You know something is coming.  Now?  Not 
so much.

I've been out to plenty of mp3j clubs at this point and all I can say is 
that the energy and the levels need Viagra. I know many here will claim 
to rock the house, yeah yeah yeah, but I am not convinced until I see 
them rock the vinyl with skills and results.

Times do change however and they will continue to change.  Some changes 
I will like, others I will abhor, such is life.

While I understand the physical problems with vinyl, I am the kind of 
guy who would never buy a kindle over a real bonafide book.

Ymmv.

-John

--- On Sat, 3/21/09, John S. Lee <jsl@twenty-hz.com> wrote:


From: John S. Lee <jsl@twenty-hz.com>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks
To: "mike guglielmini" <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Saturday, March 21, 2009, 2:01 PM


I'm with you Mike on the wording.

It is a serious stretch to call what is happening now with computers and th=
e DJ, real dj'ing.=A0 From either an etymological point of view, from a phy=
sical point of view or from a practical point of view.=A0 I know many new j=
acks love this technology, and the argument can be made that it does not re=
place skill, to some degree.

But there is skill in being in a dark club, digging through heavy crate of =
records, trying to read a label, slapping it down on a deck, getting the pi=
tch just right, and coming in at the right point.=A0 That physical activity=
 , I think, is what the crowd unconsciously grooves to, because the act of =
anticipation is actually seen as you witness a DJ take a platter off and pu=
t one one.=A0 You know something is coming.=A0 Now?=A0 Not so much.

I've been out to plenty of mp3j clubs at this point and all I can say is th=
at the energy and the levels need Viagra. I know many here will claim to ro=
ck the house, yeah yeah yeah, but I am not convinced until I see them rock =
the vinyl with skills and results.

Times do change however and they will continue to change.=A0 Some changes I=
 will like, others I will abhor, such is life.

While I understand the physical problems with vinyl, I am the kind of guy w=
ho would never buy a kindle over a real bonafide book.

Ymmv.

-John

I'm with you Mike on the wording.

It is a serious stretch to call what is happening now with computers and th=
e DJ, real dj'ing.=A0 From either an etymological point of view, from a phy=
sical point of view or from a practical point of view.=A0 I know many new j=
acks love this technology, and the argument can be made that it does not re=
place skill, to some degree.

But there is skill in being in a dark club, digging through heavy crate of =
records, trying to read a label, slapping it down on a deck, getting the pi=
tch just right, and coming in at the right point.=A0 That physical activity=
 , I think, is what the crowd unconsciously grooves to, because the act of =
anticipation is actually seen as you witness a DJ take a platter off and pu=
t one one.=A0 You know something is coming.=A0 Now?=A0 Not so much.

I've been out to plenty of mp3j clubs at this point and all I can say is th=
at the energy and the levels need Viagra. I know many here will claim to ro=
ck the house, yeah yeah yeah, but I am not convinced until I see them rock =
the vinyl with skills and results.

Times do change however and they will continue to change.=A0 Some changes I=
 will like, others I will abhor, such is life.

While I understand the physical problems with vinyl, I am the kind of guy w=
ho would never buy a kindle over a real bonafide book.

Ymmv.

-John

I'm with you Mike on the wording.

It is a serious stretch to call what is happening now with computers and th=
e DJ, real dj'ing.=A0 From either an etymological point of view, from a phy=
sical point of view or from a practical point of view.=A0 I know many new j=
acks love this technology, and the argument can be made that it does not re=
place skill, to some degree.

But there is skill in being in a dark club, digging through heavy crate of =
records, trying to read a label, slapping it down on a deck, getting the pi=
tch just right, and coming in at the right point.=A0 That physical activity=
 , I think, is what the crowd unconsciously grooves to, because the act of =
anticipation is actually seen as you witness a DJ take a platter off and pu=
t one one.=A0 You know something is coming.=A0 Now?=A0 Not so much.

I've been out to plenty of mp3j clubs at this point and all I can say is th=
at the energy and the levels need Viagra. I know many here will claim to ro=
ck the house, yeah yeah yeah, but I am not convinced until I see them rock =
the vinyl with skills and results.

Times do change however and they will continue to change.=A0 Some changes I=
 will like, others I will abhor, such is life.

While I understand the physical problems with vinyl, I am the kind of guy w=
ho would never buy a kindle over a real bonafide book.

--- On Sat, 3/21/09, John S. Lee <jsl@twenty-hz.com> wrote:


From: John S. Lee <jsl@twenty-hz.com>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks
To: "mike guglielmini" <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Saturday, March 21, 2009, 2:01 PM


I'm with you Mike on the wording.

It is a serious stretch to call what is happening now with computers and th=
e DJ, real dj'ing.=A0 From either an etymological point of view, from a phy=
sical point of view or from a practical point of view.=A0 I know many new j=
acks love this technology, and the argument can be made that it does not re=
place skill, to some degree.

But there is skill in being in a dark club, digging through heavy crate of =
records, trying to read a label, slapping it down on a deck, getting the pi=
tch just right, and coming in at the right point.=A0 That physical activity=
 , I think, is what the crowd unconsciously grooves to, because the act of =
anticipation is actually seen as you witness a DJ take a platter off and pu=
t one one.=A0 You know something is coming.=A0 Now?=A0 Not so much.

I've been out to plenty of mp3j clubs at this point and all I can say is th=
at the energy and the levels need Viagra. I know many here will claim to ro=
ck the house, yeah yeah yeah, but I am not convinced until I see them rock =
the vinyl with skills and results.

Times do change however and they will continue to change.=A0 Some changes I=
 will like, others I will abhor, such is life.

While I understand the physical problems with vinyl, I am the kind of guy w=
ho would never buy a kindle over a real bonafide book.

Ymmv.

-John

Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks


Some good points here about DJing as a physical act.  But I think with some thought this can be added back into the experience even if the source media is digital.  

And then again there have always been fakers...

I remember seeing Oakenfold at Ultra in 2001 on the main stage and he was totally faking it as he was obviously spilling champagne on the record he was supposedly playing with no effect on the mix.  It was likely just a prerecorded DAT he was playing back in those days and he pulled shit out of his crate to make it look like he was mixing.  Sort of the DJ equivalent of lip sync-ing...

Peter





----- Original Message ----
From: John S. Lee <jsl@twenty-hz.com>
To: mike guglielmini <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Saturday, March 21, 2009 11:01:04 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks

I'm with you Mike on the wording.

It is a serious stretch to call what is happening now with computers and the DJ, real dj'ing.  From either an etymological point of view, from a physical point of view or from a practical point of view.  I know many new jacks love this technology, and the argument can be made that it does not replace skill, to some degree.

But there is skill in being in a dark club, digging through heavy crate of records, trying to read a label, slapping it down on a deck, getting the pitch just right, and coming in at the right point.  That physical activity , I think, is what the crowd unconsciously grooves to, because the act of anticipation is actually seen as you witness a DJ take a platter off and put one one.  You know something is coming.  Now?  Not so much.

I've been out to plenty of mp3j clubs at this point and all I can say is that the energy and the levels need Viagra. I know many here will claim to rock the house, yeah yeah yeah, but I am not convinced until I see them rock the vinyl with skills and results.

Times do change however and they will continue to change.  Some changes I will like, others I will abhor, such is life.

While I understand the physical problems with vinyl, I am the kind of guy who would never buy a kindle over a real bonafide book.

Ymmv.

-John

Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks

Part of the problem is seeing a DJ has become the primary reason to go 
to an event for many people. This is when DJ's become icons, and then we 
make it impossible for them to live up to it.

DJ's were better back when people went to parties to party and to make 
friends, while dancing to hypnotic tunes. Dance music gave way to cool 
music. Many people have forgotten that there is a difference in playing 
music to dance to progressively, versus playing music that sounds 
awesome when driving your car blasting the ipod.

I totally agree with the ADD DJ phenomenon. I miss 3 hour sets, I miss 
progressively working with the dancers. Now you see parties with HHC 
back-to-back with fucking trance, and buildup/breakdowns every 30 
seconds. How can I dance to that?

The DJ's are better when they work with the party, instead of being some 
icon that represents the party itself.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> Some good points here about DJing as a physical act.  But I think with some thought this can be added back into the experience even if the source media is digital.  
>   
Ok, I hear you on that for real.  I think Serrano is a good compromise 
as I do think digital does have it's virtues.  But I also think 
something and a connection is lost.  An opportunity to communicate.  
Because the physicality of the DJ is as much a part of the show as the 
music.  Little things matter, IMO.

> And then again there have always been fakers...
>   

LOL!
> I remember seeing Oakenfold at Ultra in 2001 on the main stage and he was totally faking it as he was obviously spilling champagne on the record he was supposedly playing with no effect on the mix.  It was likely just a prerecorded DAT he was playing back in those days and he pulled shit out of his crate to make it look like he was mixing.  Sort of the DJ equivalent of lip sync-ing...
>   
We reach!  Another issue with digital, it CAN be faked.  You ain't 
faking with no vinyl ladies and gents.  Either you come off or step 
off.  But I do think that with the caliber of talent out there, people 
are playing great mp3j sets.  Good music, although it lacks sonically to 
me, and people do dance, which is good.  No they ain't losing thier 
heads, thier dancing and dancing is the point.  I can see that side of 
it too.

My prejudice is toward 1200's.  That is unlikely to change anytime 
soon.  At least vinyl sales are starting to pick-up, but it might just 
be the last few horses before the glue factory shuts down.

> Peter
>   

Peace PEter, good points,
John
>
>

> ----- Original Message ----
> From: John S. Lee <jsl@twenty-hz.com>
> To: mike guglielmini <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>
> Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Saturday, March 21, 2009 11:01:04 AM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks
>
> I'm with you Mike on the wording.
>
> It is a serious stretch to call what is happening now with computers and the DJ, real dj'ing.  From either an etymological point of view, from a physical point of view or from a practical point of view.  I know many new jacks love this technology, and the argument can be made that it does not replace skill, to some degree.
>
> But there is skill in being in a dark club, digging through heavy crate of records, trying to read a label, slapping it down on a deck, getting the pitch just right, and coming in at the right point.  That physical activity , I think, is what the crowd unconsciously grooves to, because the act of anticipation is actually seen as you witness a DJ take a platter off and put one one.  You know something is coming.  Now?  Not so much.
>
> I've been out to plenty of mp3j clubs at this point and all I can say is that the energy and the levels need Viagra. I know many here will claim to rock the house, yeah yeah yeah, but I am not convinced until I see them rock the vinyl with skills and results.
>
> Times do change however and they will continue to change.  Some changes I will like, others I will abhor, such is life.
>
> While I understand the physical problems with vinyl, I am the kind of guy who would never buy a kindle over a real bonafide book.
>
> Ymmv.
>
> -John
>

Word!

dreamdust wrote:
> Part of the problem is seeing a DJ has become the primary reason to go 
> to an event for many people. This is when DJ's become icons, and then 
> we make it impossible for them to live up to it.
>
> DJ's were better back when people went to parties to party and to make 
> friends, while dancing to hypnotic tunes. Dance music gave way to cool 
> music. Many people have forgotten that there is a difference in 
> playing music to dance to progressively, versus playing music that 
> sounds awesome when driving your car blasting the ipod.
>
> I totally agree with the ADD DJ phenomenon. I miss 3 hour sets, I miss 
> progressively working with the dancers. Now you see parties with HHC 
> back-to-back with fucking trance, and buildup/breakdowns every 30 
> seconds. How can I dance to that?
>
> The DJ's are better when they work with the party, instead of being 
> some icon that represents the party itself.
>

In-Reply-To: <49C49BCC.6030307@defsf.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks

Yeah, but you're not titty-twisting.  You're not "working" it 
physically.  There is a lack of force and momentum and push to the music 
that comes from those tiny physical efforts - which ave energy by the 
way.  A hard disk spinning at a constant rate is not analog - nothing is 
constant in those great sets.  You have physical energy converted to an 
analog wave and sent through massive analog speakers.  That is some pure 
shit, no quant.  A bottom that lasts forever, low-end feedback, and all 
kinds of cool stuff you can really only get with vinyl and a set of 
turntables.

That is a Digital Disc Jockey and that is the best I can do, a DDJ.  I 
mean if you're embracing the technology, might as well call it what it 
is, and peeps should take no offense.  When Jazz mutated they called it 
fusion, etc.  Why not just rock your 0's and 1's flag and get your 
groove on.  But that is not DJing in the classic sense of the word.  
There was no DJ before there we records.  Records therefore define a DJ, 
since the "D" stands for disk.

But you're still not jocking discs, you're jocking mp3's or AIFF or 
whatever - they ain't disks, so saying your have a disc involved is a 
stretch, especially since you can now use iPods etc to mix and come up 
with sets.  You are no longer bound to a disc, but you are playing 
mp3's.  MP3J is probably the most appropriate for those with pride in 
this craft.  If I was "spinning" 100% digital, this is what I would call 
myself for sure.

Sheeit my turntables are in the corner gathering some dust.  My old Rane 
is in the garage, needs a repair, and I download most of my music at 
this point.  Very rarely I gone out and supported the vinyl movement in 
the last oh 4 years?  So I'm not fronting.  I am a victim of the 
seduction of digital, which is strong. My studio is 100% digital up to 
the analog ins/outs.  My Mac is the center of my music universe.  So I 
feel it.  But I'll get the 1200's going for the kiddies.  I got like 
2000 records and stuff to share, so it wont be long.  Then they'll want 
the latest shit.  If they need the old school crap they'll borrow it 
from dad.

Gotta love living,
John

Subject: [sfraves] WR: The 27 & a 1/2 hour adventure

ok... so Yaya got to my house around like a lil after 4AM from th4e =20
City w/ Canada & Malaysia & Neighbor Michael (aka Dina Dragnfly & =20
Terri & neighbor Michael) ... I was kinda ready for them to get there =20
'cause whenever Terri gets to my house to drop me off, she always =20
needs to use the bathroom.. so i was ready!  After some chit chat, =20
hugz, & quiet laughs ('cause we were kinda loud enough as was & =20
well... every kinda noise echoes from my driveway & we were kinda loud =20
at 1st), the Sac crew took off...

Then me & Yaya (Delia aka Ms KittyCat aka Veluria something somthing =20
if you forgot who I called my yaya) went to my garage to have a catch =20
up conversation about each other & what she did that night @ Ruby Skys =20
& how Canada's set was... but yeah... we had to talk in there 'cause =20
like anywhere else in the house woulda be mondo echoing & parents were =20
still kinda like sleeping...

We trekked up to my room, talked for an hour more, then crashed out... =20
well... she was kinda still drunk, so she kinda like zonked out =20
quickstyle... then around like 11:30 AMish.. we both woke up, well, =20
apparently she was up a few times, but the 3rd/4th time she got up, I =20
woke up too... then we had breakfast, my Mom made her some lumpia, I =20
made her some eggs & me too & sausages... we chilled for a while, got =20
ready, & left my house by 3:30-ish...

After 2 bus rides, a bart ride, a stop in SOMA/ downtown for coffee,  =20
shoes, a chance for Yaya to soak up some City Life, & a looooooooong =20
ass Muni ride to Ocean Beach... we got to the beach by like 6:45ish & =20
well... it was Sunset & we were just takin' in the beauty of it all: =20
the beach, the water, the reflection of the sun on the water, the sun =20
going down, I mean.. it was like just 1 of those moment in time things =20
ya know, 'cause of the reason we were all there & the enviorment, =20
surroundings kinda dealie... slowly more and more people started =20
showing up (1/2 friends, 1/2 family, oh oh ohohoh... even Joey & =20
Apollo showed up) & after like an hour of like talking and =20
reaquainting with people, oh yeah, we all just like sat around the =20
bonfire & shared our Dave stories... I mean.. it was there were hella =20
tears & mondo laughs & stuff... I kinda shared a few me and Dave =20
stories... it kinda felt good to vent/ release all that stuff, but =20
hearing more stories about Dave just seriously made me miss him more :\

I mean... so like I do wanna say thanks to alota y'all on here 'cause =20
some of you know that like since November, including Dave, like 11-12 =20
of my relatives have also passed, so it hasn't been like mondo good =20
head space for me really the past few months... but I am getting =20
stronger from it & harnessing this energy to turn into something =20
positive & yummy.. so Thanks to you SF Ravers who have helped me get =20
through this!!

By 10:08 PM, me & Yaya caught a ride with Catt (old skool SFR if =20
anyone here remembers her/ Dave's sister inlaw) back to SOMA for Grime =20
City.. I mean... we coulda stayed longer I guess... but I really =20
needed to get to Anu at a decent time & had a garunteed ride =20
already... my Homies from Bakersfield, Wish & Deeds aka HD4000, were =20
up to spin a dubstep set... which btw, was fuckin siiiiiiiiiiiiiick!!! =20
  They dropped all the dubstep choonage they made & remixed & =20
ooooooooh... it was Soooo yummy!!!  They closed the last like 20 =20
minutes of their set w/ raga...I mean.. by that time of night, I was =20
dancing my ass off on the floor!!  Before them, DubsWorth was spinning =20
some bad ass dubstep too... I mean... he even dropped some Grime in it =20
too & like a speed garage track or 2 & it was just ILL :)  Sam Supa =20
opened up the night & just played this chill dubstep set & dropped =20
some like old skool hip hop here & there during his set!!

The crowd started out light, then by like 11:30-1, it was packed, then =20
it died down again , but the vibe was heeeeeella fuckin' strong =20
still... & the dancefloor was never empty... & it was Awesome spendin' =20
time the DubStep Familia :) oh yeah.. so like there was this dude I =20
met on the dubstep.fm channel on irc, snf, who said to look for the =20
crazy white on the dance floor 'cause I told him I'd be the hyper =20
Filipino dude bouncin around Anu... well.. I kinda went up to every =20
white dude on the dance floor & asked if he was the crazy white dude =20
on the dance floor.. none... so I even started goin up to dudes who =20
weren't white.. but they were crazy guys on the dance floor, so why =20
not.. still none :(  But I made alota new friends, so that's all that =20
mattered :)  Oh yeah.. even the new bouncer dude... oh my gosh... he =20
is sooo Awesome!!  Good energy!!

So they didn't stop spinning til like a quarter after 2AM... kicked it =20
around Anu for a while longer.. then kicked it outside w/ 'til like =20
2:45ish... then me & Yaya went to Denny's & kinda stayed there =20
literally cracked out tired laughing, eating a sampler plate, drinking =20
ice tea, & coffee for almost 2 1/2 hours... then when the crazy lady =20
who sat in the booth next to ours started talking to us & saying that =20
we look good in pictures, we took that as a sign to leave.. & it was =20
5:35AMish already... we got to BART by 10 'til & when we got =20
downstairs, the train was already waiting... 2 trains later, go to =20
DelNorte & said my byws to my Baby Sis... then by the time I got outta =20
the station to the bus stop, the bus was there!  Hello 2day.. this was =20
odd for a Saturday... but  I got home by 7:15 & even called Yaya on my =20
phone 'cause I wanted to like atleast keep her some company while she =20
waited in Richmond for the AmTrack :)

Yeah.. i'm still kinda raver jett from the weekend still... lol.. so =20
that's why I'm still up & figured I'd do my WR while i'm like still =20
kinda up-ish, but gonna night night soon!!  Hope y'all have a good Day!!


Peace=3D->
Just Me=3D->
Osby {8O)

----- Original Message ----
From: John S. Lee <jsl@twenty-hz.com>
To: mike guglielmini <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Saturday, March 21, 2009 11:01:04 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks

I'm with you Mike on the wording.

It is a serious stretch to call what is happening now with computers and th=
e DJ, real dj'ing.  From either an etymological point of view, from a physi=
cal point of view or from a practical point of view.  I know many new jacks=
 love this technology, and the argument can be made that it does not replac=
e skill, to some degree.

But there is skill in being in a dark club, digging through heavy crate of =
records, trying to read a label, slapping it down on a deck, getting the pi=
tch just right, and coming in at the right point.  That physical activity ,=
 I think, is what the crowd unconsciously grooves to, because the act of an=
ticipation is actually seen as you witness a DJ take a platter off and put =
one one.  You know something is coming.  Now?  Not so much.

I've been out to plenty of mp3j clubs at this point and all I can say is th=
at the energy and the levels need Viagra. I know many here will claim to ro=
ck the house, yeah yeah yeah, but I am not convinced until I see them rock =
the vinyl with skills and results.

Times do change however and they will continue to change.  Some changes I w=
ill like, others I will abhor, such is life.

While I understand the physical problems with vinyl, I am the kind of guy w=
ho would never buy a kindle over a real bonafide book.

Ymmv.

-John

On Fri, Mar 20, 2009 at 9:17 AM, Matt Stone <matthew.d.stone@gmail.com>wrot=
e:

          =20
       =20
First, when did DJs ever have musical skills?
Ok seriously tho, if you are still doing the beatmatching I don't see why
it
matters if you do it on plain vinyl, cd decks, or a digital vinyl
solution.
  The only time I call foul is if you use software to do the beatmatching
for
you.  Also, beatmatching with the bpm detect function on new gear is
borderline ;)

However, there is one case where I think having software align all the
beats
for you is okay, and that is if you are doing a reasonably complex live PA
with something like Ableton.  If you have more then three tracks playing
at
once, I personally think its acceptable to have software help.

Just my $0.02

I'm with you Mike on the wording.

It is a serious stretch to call what is happening now with computers and th=
e DJ, real dj'ing.  From either an etymological point of view, from a physi=
cal point of view or from a practical point of view.  I know many new jacks=
 love this technology, and the argument can be made that it does not replac=
e skill, to some degree.

But there is skill in being in a dark club, digging through heavy crate of =
records, trying to read a label, slapping it down on a deck, getting the pi=
tch just right, and coming in at the right point.  That physical activity ,=
 I think, is what the crowd unconsciously grooves to, because the act of an=
ticipation is actually seen as you witness a DJ take a platter off and put =
one one.  You know something is coming.  Now?  Not so much.

I've been out to plenty of mp3j clubs at this point and all I can say is th=
at the energy and the levels need Viagra. I know many here will claim to ro=
ck the house, yeah yeah yeah, but I am not convinced until I see them rock =
the vinyl with skills and results.

Times do change however and they will continue to change.  Some changes I w=
ill like, others I will abhor, such is life.

While I understand the physical problems with vinyl, I am the kind of guy w=
ho would never buy a kindle over a real bonafide book.

Ymmv.

-John

--- On Sat, 3/21/09, John S. Lee <jsl@twenty-hz.com> wrote:


From: John S. Lee <jsl@twenty-hz.com>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
Cc: "mike guglielmini" <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Saturday, March 21, 2009, 6:02 PM


dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote: 
Some good points here about DJing as a physical act.  But I think with some thought this can be added back into the experience even if the source media is digital.  
  Ok, I hear you on that for real.  I think Serrano is a good compromise as I do think digital does have it's virtues.  But I also think something and a connection is lost.  An opportunity to communicate.  Because the physicality of the DJ is as much a part of the show as the music.  Little things matter, IMO.


And then again there have always been fakers...
  
LOL!

I remember seeing Oakenfold at Ultra in 2001 on the main stage and he was totally faking it as he was obviously spilling champagne on the record he was supposedly playing with no effect on the mix.  It was likely just a prerecorded DAT he was playing back in those days and he pulled shit out of his crate to make it look like he was mixing.  Sort of the DJ equivalent of lip sync-ing...
  We reach!  Another issue with digital, it CAN be faked.  You ain't faking with no vinyl ladies and gents.  Either you come off or step off.  But I do think that with the caliber of talent out there, people are playing great mp3j sets.  Good music, although it lacks sonically to me, and people do dance, which is good.  No they ain't losing thier heads, thier dancing and dancing is the point.  I can see that side of it too.

My prejudice is toward 1200's.  That is unlikely to change anytime soon.  At least vinyl sales are starting to pick-up, but it might just be the last few horses before the glue factory shuts down.


Peter
  
Peace PEter, good points,
John





----- Original Message ----
From: John S. Lee <jsl@twenty-hz.com>
To: mike guglielmini <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Saturday, March 21, 2009 11:01:04 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] laptops replacing decks

I'm with you Mike on the wording.

It is a serious stretch to call what is happening now with computers and the DJ, real dj'ing.  From either an etymological point of view, from a physical point of view or from a practical point of view.  I know many new jacks love this technology, and the argument can be made that it does not replace skill, to some degree.

But there is skill in being in a dark club, digging through heavy crate of records, trying to read a label, slapping it down on a deck, getting the pitch just right, and coming in at the right point.  That physical activity , I think, is what the crowd unconsciously grooves to, because the act of anticipation is actually seen as you witness a DJ take a platter off and put one one.  You know something is coming.  Now?  Not so much.

I've been out to plenty of mp3j clubs at this point and all I can say is that the energy and the levels need Viagra. I know many here will claim to rock the house, yeah yeah yeah, but I am not convinced until I see them rock the vinyl with skills and results.

Times do change however and they will continue to change.  Some changes I will like, others I will abhor, such is life.

While I understand the physical problems with vinyl, I am the kind of guy who would never buy a kindle over a real bonafide book.

Ymmv.

-John

mike guglielmini wrote:
  
mp3j

beats
for you is okay, and that is if you are doing a reasonably complex live PA

at
once, I personally think its acceptable to have software help.

Just my $0.02

outta there before something bad really happens.  You just got ganked 
that is all.  And if you're in South Beach, take solace, it isn't 
Miami.  LOL!  Miami is far worse, especially for the uninitiated.  LOL.  
I can't stop laughing....now I have to call my brother in Miami to relay 
this story.  More laughs in store!

Good luck, get home quick.

Subject: [sfraves] [NRR]  How not to get jacked in Miami or Miami Beach

Rule #1 know the truth -
Miami is the fraud capital of the world, period.  It used to be the 
murder capital of the world, but things have calmed down.  If you need a 
credit card, stolen goods, cars or you simply want to run a confidence 
scam Miami is your place.

Oh and don't bother with the cops.  They are corrupt.

Rule #2 money rules -
Fuck LA, Hollywood and Wall Street, they got nothing on Miami where you 
can obtain anything for a decent price.  And I do mean anything.  The 
legends of Tijuana do not compare to the truth of Miami.

Rule#3 foreigners suck in Miami -
Ever since they stopped killing German and Euro tourists we've seen an 
increase in the numbers of the Euro herd taking over South beach and 
Miami.  Be careful, once they come to Miami, they get infected with the 
Miami virus and what was a nice little Euro chick becomes a hard core 
scammer.  It is also a top recruiting ground for porn people, and they 
are by definition sketchy oftentimes.

My single bit of advice is this, and I am from there.  If you're 
traveling to Miami or South Beach you had better know a native.  Before 
I go I set all of my shit up ahead of time, I know which clubs I'll be 
going to , make sure my brothers have obtained everything I need for a 
good time, and I am usually with or part of a larger "posse" of, er 
natives who are about business.  The surest way not to get ganked in 
Miami is for there to be immediate and severe consequences for even 
trying - it would have been a different outcome had you been 
"introduced" through a trusted native channel.  You might be out $200 
but not much more than that, if you get my drift.  If you got all that 
set up, you should have a pretty good time.  That place is not for 
someone not connected to the city in some way shape or form.

Damn, what a place.

-John

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: women in miami


Ok, I've been getting a lot of grief on this.  I know that this is a criminal offence.  My suggestion was just that small claims is an easy and low risk way to get SOME of your money back.  Small claims in California goes to $7500 BTW but as I said I don't know about Florida.

I have actually done this under somewhat different circumstances. I recovered the money that was stolen from me, in that case by a former employee.  And you can file a small claim suit for less than the total amount lost or stolen, you just give up the right to collect any remaining amount.  At least that's how I understood it at the time.

Good luck getting police attention for a theft of this sort.  What they will do is take a report from you and file it.  What they won't do is hunt down the perp and bring them to "justice" or get any of your money back.  That is unless this is part of a larger set of crimes or they are looking for this person for other reasons.

Peter

Rule #1 know the truth -
Miami is the fraud capital of the world, period.=A0 It used to be the murde=
r capital of the world, but things have calmed down.=A0 If you need a credi=
t card, stolen goods, cars or you simply want to run a confidence scam Miam=
i is your place.

Oh and don't bother with the cops.=A0 They are corrupt.

Rule #2 money rules -
Fuck LA, Hollywood and Wall Street, they got nothing on Miami where you can=
 obtain anything for a decent price.=A0 And I do mean anything.=A0 The lege=
nds of Tijuana do not compare to the truth of Miami.

Rule#3 foreigners suck in Miami -
Ever since they stopped killing German and Euro tourists we've seen an incr=
ease in the numbers of the Euro herd taking over South beach and Miami.=A0 =
Be careful, once they come to Miami, they get infected with the Miami virus=
 and what was a nice little Euro chick becomes a hard core scammer.=A0 It i=
s also a top recruiting ground for porn people, and they are by definition =
sketchy oftentimes.

My single bit of advice is this, and I am from there.=A0 If you're travelin=
g to Miami or South Beach you had better know a native.=A0 Before I go I se=
t all of my shit up ahead of time, I know which clubs I'll be going to , ma=
ke sure my brothers have obtained everything I need for a good time, and I =
am usually with or part of a larger "posse" of, er natives who are about bu=
siness.=A0 The surest way not to get ganked in Miami is for there to be imm=
ediate and severe consequences for even trying - it would have been a diffe=
rent outcome had you been "introduced" through a trusted native channel.=A0=
 You might be out $200 but not much more than that, if you get my drift.=A0=
 If you got all that set up, you should have a pretty good time.=A0 That pl=
ace is not for someone not connected to the city in some way shape or form.

Damn, what a place.

-John

Ok, I've been getting a lot of grief on this.=A0 I know that this is a crim=
inal offence.=A0 My suggestion was just that small claims is an easy and lo=
w risk way to get SOME of your money back.=A0 Small claims in California go=
es to $7500 BTW but as I said I don't know about Florida.

I have actually done this under somewhat different circumstances. I recover=
ed the money that was stolen from me, in that case by a former employee.=A0=
 And you can file a small claim suit for less than the total amount lost or=
 stolen, you just give up the right to collect any remaining amount.=A0 At =
least that's how I understood it at the time.

Good luck getting police attention for a theft of this sort.=A0 What they w=
ill do is take a report from you and file it.=A0 What they won't do is hunt=
 down the perp and bring them to "justice" or get any of your money back.=
=A0 That is unless this is part of a larger set of crimes or they are looki=
ng for this person for other reasons.

Peter

> Subject: [sfraves] [NRR] How not to get jacked in Miami or Miami Beach
> To: "'SFR'" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Date: Wednesday, March 25, 2009, 12:06 PM
>
>
> Rule #1 know the truth -
> Miami is the fraud capital of the world, period.  It used to be the murder capital of the world, but things have calmed down.  If you need a credit card, stolen goods, cars or you simply want to run a confidence scam Miami is your place.
>
> Oh and don't bother with the cops.  They are corrupt.
>
> Rule #2 money rules -
> Fuck LA, Hollywood and Wall Street, they got nothing on Miami where you can obtain anything for a decent price.  And I do mean anything.  The legends of Tijuana do not compare to the truth of Miami.
>
> Rule#3 foreigners suck in Miami -
> Ever since they stopped killing German and Euro tourists we've seen an increase in the numbers of the Euro herd taking over South beach and Miami.  Be careful, once they come to Miami, they get infected with the Miami virus and what was a nice little Euro chick becomes a hard core scammer.  It is also a top recruiting ground for porn people, and they are by definition sketchy oftentimes.
>
> My single bit of advice is this, and I am from there.  If you're traveling to Miami or South Beach you had better know a native.  Before I go I set all of my shit up ahead of time, I know which clubs I'll be going to , make sure my brothers have obtained everything I need for a good time, and I am usually with or part of a larger "posse" of, er natives who are about business.  The surest way not to get ganked in Miami is for there to be immediate and severe consequences for even trying - it would have been a different outcome had you been "introduced" through a trusted native channel.  You might be out $200 but not much more than that, if you get my drift.  If you got all that set up, you should have a pretty good time.  That place is not for someone not connected to the city in some way shape or form.
>
> Damn, what a place.
>
> -John
>
>

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Oh Mike, don't get me wrong I *am* one of those fools.  But just like 
every other fool who thinks "DC" or "NYC" or Chicago, etc., we all think 
we come from the baddest part of the planet.  Until you go to a bona 
fide 3rd world country and you see that even at it's worst the U.S.  is 
overall punkified and full of blowhards.   There is no ghetto in the US 
that compares to a Brasilian or Indian slum.  Nobody here would survive 
Sadr City or instance. We just are well armed, that's all!

Dude, I would be furious if I were you.  Your anger is warranted, but it 
is good you're moving past it so quickly.

Yeah the fucked up thing about Miami is that I hear these stories all 
the time and just wonder wtf?  And I ask myself "Do people still live 
there?  Most of the mugs I grew up with in Miami got the fuck out if 
they were smart.  The dumb ones, they are dead or in jail.

It's not a hard city per se anymore, it is just scummy and scammy at 
this point.  Everyone is so well armed, tough has got nothing to do with 
it.  But you have to be wiley to live there now, so it is more about 
brains and wit than brawn - everyone is on he take, everyone.  But I'm 
preaching to the choir, you know wassup.

Ok man, back to it.  Nice meeting you, and when I am in Mia soon enough 
you and I should link up.

-John

> Rule #1 know the truth -
> Miami is the fraud capital of the world, period.  It used to be the murder capital of the world, but things have calmed down.  If you need a credit card, stolen goods, cars or you simply want to run a confidence scam Miami is your place.
>
> Oh and don't bother with the cops.  They are corrupt.
>
> Rule #2 money rules -
> Fuck LA, Hollywood and Wall Street, they got nothing on Miami where you can obtain anything for a decent price.  And I do mean anything.  The legends of Tijuana do not compare to the truth of Miami.
>
> Rule#3 foreigners suck in Miami -
> Ever since they stopped killing German and Euro tourists we've seen an increase in the numbers of the Euro herd taking over South beach and Miami.  Be careful, once they come to Miami, they get infected with the Miami virus and what was a nice little Euro chick becomes a hard core scammer.  It is also a top recruiting ground for porn people, and they are by definition sketchy oftentimes.
>
> My single bit of advice is this, and I am from there.  If you're traveling to Miami or South Beach you had better know a native.  Before I go I set all of my shit up ahead of time, I know which clubs I'll be going to , make sure my brothers have obtained everything I need for a good time, and I am usually with or part of a larger "posse" of, er natives who are about business.  The surest way not to get ganked in Miami is for there to be immediate and severe consequences for even trying - it would have been a different outcome had you been "introduced" through a trusted native channel.  You might be out $200 but not much more than that, if you get my drift.  If you got all that set up, you should have a pretty good time.  That place is not for someone not connected to the city in some way shape or form.
>
> Damn, what a place.
>
> -John

This thread really sums up for me the reason why I stopped going to WMC a few years ago.  The gigs were fun and the networking was pretty helpful, but in that environment of exhorbitant, stupid cost of living/partying, a culture of oafish dumbshits throughout the nightlife sphere, and a cavalcade of hot-but-obviously-no-fun women- yuck.  Everyone seemed to be out to prove something.  
 
..and that's south beach!  I can't even imagine how fucked Miami proper is.

"Girls are hot, wearing less than bikinis, rock man lovers, driving Lamborghinis" indeed.

Now, Amsterdam Dance Event?  That I can get with. ;)

-G

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: RG: bSP: YUKSEK - se soir!!!!


LOL - appreciate the kind protective words - but I have Lurked long enough not to flash to the lists drama and no you won't drag me into "vinyl or digital... dead horse debate" - I DJ both vinyl and cd's and play whatever I can get my hands on! 
I  am Mojo aka Ofer. I live in SF and have been raving for many years beginning my early introduction into the scene in London (where I spent  5+ yrs) continuing to SF, a couple of years in NYC and back to SF for a total of 10+ years in the US.
I have two incredible little girls who like to "Shake their Coconuts" to Jr. Senior from the DFA remixes. My daughters have already frequented Love Fest, How Weird, Orgeon Country fair- amongst many other SF parades -being 2yrs and 5 yrs - kind of tough getting into the clubs and UG's yet ;-) but dancing is big at home and I hope it remains a big escape/outlet for them for the rest of their lives!!
I like many different styles of music and drift to extremes often - always trying to satisfy my aural pleasure - music and sound have no limits!
 
I have enjoyed these lists for a while now. I hope they continue to survive and one day some of the great people who left will return - I miss some of the more quality postings but have learned to ignore the crapy ones very easily!!
I will gladly bring back a Yuksek review to the list and am always glad to meet new people and make new friends here in SF or really anywhere!

Out of the lurking closet - oh I feel so exposed :-}
Mojo

> Rule #1 know the truth -
> Miami is the fraud capital of the world, period.  It used to be the murder capital of the world, but things have calmed down.  If you need a credit card, stolen goods, cars or you simply want to run a confidence scam Miami is your place.
>
> Oh and don't bother with the cops.  They are corrupt.
>
> Rule #2 money rules -
> Fuck LA, Hollywood and Wall Street, they got nothing on Miami where you can obtain anything for a decent price.  And I do mean anything.  The legends of Tijuana do not compare to the truth of Miami.
>
> Rule#3 foreigners suck in Miami -
> Ever since they stopped killing German and Euro tourists we've seen an increase in the numbers of the Euro herd taking over South beach and Miami.  Be careful, once they come to Miami, they get infected with the Miami virus and what was a nice little Euro chick becomes a hard core scammer.  It is also a top recruiting ground for porn people, and they are by definition sketchy oftentimes.
>
> My single bit of advice is this, and I am from there.  If you're traveling to Miami or South Beach you had better know a native.  Before I go I set all of my shit up ahead of time, I know which clubs I'll be going to , make sure my brothers have obtained everything I need for a good time, and I am usually with or part of a larger "posse" of, er natives who are about business.  The surest way not to get ganked in Miami is for there to be immediate and severe consequences for even trying - it would have been a different outcome had you been "introduced" through a trusted native channel.  You might be out $200 but not much more than that, if you get my drift.  If you got all that set up, you should have a pretty good time.  That place is not for someone not connected to the city in some way shape or form.
>
> Damn, what a place.
>
> -John

Cc: Jas Strong <jasmine@heroicrobot.com>; mike guglielmini <djdarkchyld@yahoo.com>; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Wednesday, March 25, 2009 9:01:59 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: women in miami


This thread really sums up for me the reason why I stopped going to WMC a few years ago.  The gigs were fun and the networking was pretty helpful, but in that environment of exhorbitant, stupid cost of living/partying, a culture of oafish dumbshits throughout the nightlife sphere, and a cavalcade of hot-but-obviously-no-fun women- yuck.  Everyone seemed to be out to prove something.  

..and that's south beach!  I can't even imagine how fucked Miami proper is.

"Girls are hot, wearing less than bikinis, rock man lovers, driving Lamborghinis" indeed.

Now, Amsterdam Dance Event?  That I can get with. ;)

-G

This thread really sums up for me the reason why I stopped going to WMC a few years ago.  The gigs were fun and the networking was pretty helpful, but in that environment of exhorbitant, stupid cost of living/partying, a culture of oafish dumbshits throughout the nightlife sphere, and a cavalcade of hot-but-obviously-no-fun women- yuck.  Everyone seemed to be out to prove something.  

..and that's south beach!  I can't even imagine how fucked Miami proper is.

"Girls are hot, wearing less than bikinis, rock man lovers, driving Lamborghinis" indeed.

Now, Amsterdam Dance Event?  That I can get with. ;)

-G

EB 5 - The E.B. Dream Team

Saturday, April 4th, 2009
Mezzanine (444 Jessie St.) 
9pm-4am

Cost if on the 700+ person list: (signup box @ EvilBreaks.com)
The 1st 100 arrivals - FREE!
The next 100 arrivals - $5
All other listees half-price until the list closes @ 11pm - $10
Door Cost: $20 


In keeping with past E.B. Anniversary shows, we want to thank everyone for supporting us in the past couple of years, and although this lineup is so insane we can't do it completely free for hundreds of people like we've been doing, we hope that you like what we can offer. Sign up is now open down below......

This show has been 5 years in the making, & we have decided to go HUGE!!! A ridiculous lineup, a ridiculous venue, a ridiculous price......You know how we do, & with this show, we're going to put everything we've ever done to shame. Get ready.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: FAKTION Friday 2.27.9 ACID CIRCUS (DROID) & SNOEK

--------------090202090601050804040903
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

****

Friday, 27 March 2009

R A Y presents:

F A K T I O N : D R O I D   B E H A V I O R: A C I D   C I R C U S

Friday, 27 March 2009
ACID CIRCUS (DROID| LA)
SNOEK (Good Bad Guy | Faktion | SF)
visuals by HEROIC ROBOT ( http://www.heroicrobot.com/ )
live webcast via DEFSF:Radio Integrated ( http://radio.defsf.com:1200/ )


YES! That's correct, we've got ACID CIRCUS coming up THIS FRIDAY.  Do
we really need to speak to Droid Behavior's role in LA Techno, or how
these guys are fixtures at DEMF?  Well fine: Acid Circus has long
established themselves along with creative parner Drumcell in the
creation of some of the best warehouse, desert and essentially any
location they've chosen to play at, in and around Los Angeles, and are
well known throughout the US and elsewhere.  THIS FRIDAY, the preparty
starts with Droid residents Subversive and DeanpauL at Killswitch
Happy Hour at Underground SF, and then moves to Faktion at Anu to
finish the night!

////////////////

Half of the founders of Droid Behavior and Droid Recordings, ACID CIRCUS
is comprised of brothers Vidal and Vangelis Vargas.  No strangers to
tweaking and freqing everything within ear shot, over the last 5 years
the members of acid circus have constantly displayed the art of techno
live performance. Dropping tracks, remixes, samples, mashups, left
hooks, and techno grime in and out of the mix has become an ultimate
trip in pure crowd reaction at LA undergrounds.
http://www.myspace.com/acidcircus

Having played in locales as diverse as the Netherlands and the Middle East,
SNOEK, aka That Fucking Guy/Meekrob heads up his own parties yet remains
humble and works tirelessly to further the local techno scene any way he can.
http://www.myspace.com/snoek

////////////////

See you on the dance floor!

4th Fridays @ Anu


Anu-Bar
43 Sixth St., San Francisco, CA
21+ Cost: $5 after 10pm NO GUESTLIST

Official Links:
http://www.faktionsf.com/
http://www.defsf.com/radiointegrated http://radio.defsf.com:1200/
http://www.droidbehavior.com/


///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////****

west coast techno articles, news, links, music & events

++++techno news & info: def-announce-subscribe@defsf.com

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Sat.Apr.4th [KONTROL] w/ Pier Bucci LIVE (Chile) + Jeremy P.

don't miss the free sets down in the audio section! ;)
